story:
A Brief History of This Project

In 2010, Rob and Kristi began their journey to Nepal to work with children in two orphanages, most of whom were former Kamlari (indentured servants). What they experienced in this work changed their lives.

Until then, it had been so easy to live as though what was happening "over there" was just an evening news clip, but after living with the children day after day, learning each of their unique backgrounds, and seeing the brilliance of their beautiful personalities, these were no longer distant stories.

This was personal. This was real.

Today, Rob and Kristi's goal to see an end to child slavery is enormous, no doubt. But they have a steadfast belief in the power of humanity and community--faith and conviction that what we can do together is greater than the sum of our individual efforts.

Being educated in counseling and human development, they launched a teacher and social worker training program in 2014 in cooperation with a Kathmandu orphanage and nearby school. Rob worked stateside and Kristi left for Nepal to organize and lead the first of what they hoped would be many workshops to come. This effort was a true leap of faith into the unknown. The first challenge would be to show the value of such training to a skeptical (at best) group of school officials, social workers and community members.

By the end of October 2014, the first workshop was complete--and it was an absolute success!

Hardened hearts were changed. Perspectives were shifted. And, in a tremendous display of support for the continuation of this training program, the principal of the local school extended an invitation to use her school, her staff of 30, and her 700 students as the first training partnership in Kathmandu!

Culturally, socially and emotionally, this level of commitment is nothing short of a very big deal!

Our training is focused on helping the children build shame resiliency skills, a sense of worthiness, and courage. Building a practitioner and community support network for children to flourish in the future is our primary goal. A stretch goal for 2015 is to hold additional workshops for some of the young women who were former Kamlari, and who are now beginning to build their futures as independent adults. As they set out on their own and pursue their educational or career endeavors, they are the most vulnerable to falling back into the cycle of poverty, and we want to help ensure they receive additional support on their new path.

(This excerpt from the Girl Rising documentary provides an accurate background on the Kamlari system in Nepal.)

A quote from Sunita's beautiful creative writing journal (shared with permission):

"Believe in yourself! Have faith in your abilities! Without a humble but reasonable confidence in your own powers, you cannot be successful or happy."


What We Need & What You Get

We have an immediate goal, a stretch goal, and long-term goals for our project. Here's the breakdown and nitty gritty of each:

  • Immediate Goal: Our first objective is to return to Kathmandu to hold another workshop for the 30 teachers waiting for us. To do this, we need to raise $5,000 to cover expenses. This accounts for all expenses to hold three 10-person workshops including facility rental, materials and supplies. Every dollar donated directly supports this workshop, and the time loss away from our "normal work" to facilitate these events is our personal donation (i.e. we do not earn any income from holding these training workshops). There will be no fee to the school nor the teachers to participate, and we want to eliminate all other indirect costs, as well. In our 2014 workshop, funded by our own financial contribution, participants received all workshop materials and supplies (even pens and paper are expensive luxuries in Nepal!); meals and snacks were provided for three full days; clean bottled water was plentiful; and safe transportation to and from the meeting location was assured for each participant (most of whom were women). The average annual income in Nepal is less than $300 per year and does not adequately support a family's needs, so we also provided each participant with a stipend to help offset their lost wages for their three days in the workshop. All of the above will be provided again in 2015's workshops.
  • Stretch Goal: Raising an additional $1,500 allows us to broaden our reach and hold a fourth workshop specifically for young women who are ex-Kamlari.  Using the research and methodology of Dr. Brené Brown, in which Rob and Kristi are both certified, this workshop will support the girls in cultivating a courage practice and the shame resiliency skills that support their journey towards future life goals.
  • Longterm Project Goals: Once we have raised a total of $15,000, we will be able to accomplish all of the above, plus launch a self-sustaining fundraising model to continue annual workshops going forward, as well as beginning our new project--The Amai Program. Amai is the Nepali word for grandmother, and our project will partner local women with orphanages to create a community-supported cooperative effort that provides nurturance to orphaned children while creating meaningful work and fair wages for local women. More information about our project goals, including The Amai Program, can be found on our website.
PERKS!
When you make the decision to contribute towards this project, the size of your generosity directly correlates with the number of people we are able to help. Here are the perks available to supporters of this project:

  • Perks from Nepal! We shopped at local vendors in Nepal who sell their handicrafts, and support fair labor for their crafters, to find some great gifts! Each item is unique and handmade; colors and details will vary.
  • Books and DVDs! In addition to these amazing Nepal handicrafts, you can learn more about the methodology we use in our workshops as well as the issues facing girls living in developing countries. Two of our favorites pieces of work are perks that will bring depth and knowledge of the work we are doing to donors who wish the engage more profoundly.


This Indiegogo campaign is set up to disperse all funds raised, even if we do not meet our full fundraising goal, because every dollar raised helps to make a difference in the continuation our work. In addition, perks are not dependent on meeting the total fundraising objective nor the campaign timelines, but will instead be sent at the time of your contribution, based upon the perk/donation level in which you choose to participate.

The Indiegogo processing fees for this type of campaign are a bit higher than campaigns that must be fully funded within a timeline, so we understand that some individuals might choose to opt out of perks in order to have more of their contribution be used for program goals. If this is your preference, please just send us an email to let us know.

We will continue to fundraise through various channels until we meet our campaign goal. Even after this Indiegogo campaign ends, the opportunity to support this project in the future through one-time support or monthly ongoing support is explained on our website.


    The Impact, Challenges & Risks

    Our first workshop in 2014 was truly a labor of love and faith. Nearly a year of pre-planning and curriculum development time was invested before we even arrived in Kathmandu. And, we went into the project with an awareness that we would encounter bumps.

    Having never used our curriculum beyond a Western audience, we knew there would be work to bridge cultural, social and language barriers. And, there was. We knew that navigating the logistics of holding a workshop in Nepal would be challenging. And, it was.

    Because of our existing experience in Nepal, we were ready for teaching without reliable access to electricity, always without heat, with the daily chore of navigating congested dirt roads to our meeting location, with shooing away various farm animals along the way, and, most heartwarming, with making time in our busy teaching schedule to play with local kids and gain the trust of the community.

    Now viewed as an extremely successful "pilot" project, our work in 2014 has enabled us to refine our curriculum and address particular regional topics in more depth. Additionally, we've built lasting relationships with supporters in Kathmandu who are ready to help us bring this work to more of the people who need it most. And while we are already very prepared for the challenges of this project, having strengthened our network in 2014 provides us with an additional level of support that only comes with community "buy in".

    Training teachers and social workers in our curriculum helps them to provide better support to the children with whom they work and to support the children's long-term development. Obstacles we may face as we expand this work are primarily in cultivating or deepening relationships with those in Kathmandu who can assist with these objectives.

    In the months following the workshops, we believe it will be important to facilitate ongoing check-ins with the teachers who receive training in order to ensure that the ideas stick. We have developed a plan to accomplish this by using web-based teleconferencing. The obvious challenge is making the technology available to all who need it and maintaining participation when we are no longer physically in Nepal. We have verbal support of two Kathmandu organizations to help with this goal, and we will need to continue cultivating those relationships to ensure success.

    Continuing our fundraising efforts will also be vitally important to ensure the project's continuation and growth. To address this, we have created the option for supporters to make one-time, as well as monthly, contributions on our website. We have also developed a marketing plan that we intend to be self-sustaining, and we plan to launch that campaign once our current fundraising objectives are met and allow us to invest in the materials needed for that endeavor.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know there are folks reading this who believe in the work we are trying to accomplish yet aren't able to make a financial contribution, but that doesn't mean you can't help. If you would like to help us further our project goals, here are some ways you can help:

    • Help us to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign! This is the single biggest thing you can do to help us! Share this campaign page on your social media sites like Facebook, Twitter and anywhere else that you are connected. Email your friends and family. Chat up your neighbor. However you can spread the word, you will be making a big difference!
    • Ask for contributions to this campaign in lieu of birthday or special occasion gifts. The $50 spent on Valentine's candy and flowers that will only last a few days would make a big difference to this campaign! If just 100 people made this contribution, we would meet our first goal!
    • Sell something on eBay, Craigslist or Etsy, and contribute the money to this campaign. Get your friends to join you and hold a garage/yard sale!
    • If you think a little doesn't make a difference, think again! Use our website to make a monthly pledge. Over time, small contributions add up to big support!
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Get the word out any way you can!

    There are many, many worthy causes to support in the world. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for considering the work we are trying to do!
story_txt:
A Brief History of This Project
 
In 2010, Rob and Kristi began their journey to Nepal to work with children in two orphanages, most of whom were former Kamlari (indentured servants). What they experienced in this work changed their lives. 

Until then, it had been so easy to live as though what was happening "over there" was just an evening news clip, but after living with the children day after day, learning each of their unique backgrounds, and seeing the brilliance of their beautiful personalities, these were no longer distant stories. This was personal. This was real.
Today, Rob and Kristi's goal to see an end to child slavery is enormous, no doubt. But they have a steadfast belief in the power of humanity and community--faith and conviction that what we can do together is greater than the sum of our individual efforts. 
Being educated in counseling and human development, they launched a teacher and social worker training program in 2014 in cooperation with a Kathmandu orphanage and nearby school. Rob worked stateside and Kristi left for Nepal to organize and lead the first of what they hoped would be many workshops to come. This effort was a true leap of faith into the unknown. The first challenge would be to show the value of such training to a skeptical (at best) group of school officials, social workers and community members.

By the end of October 2014, the first workshop was complete--and it was an absolute success! Hardened hearts were changed. Perspectives were shifted. And, in a tremendous display of support for the continuation of this training program, the principal of the local school extended an invitation to use her school, her staff of 30, and her 700 students as the first training partnership in Kathmandu!
Culturally, socially and emotionally, this level of commitment is nothing short of a very big deal!
Our training is focused on helping the children build shame resiliency skills, a sense of worthiness, and courage. Building a practitioner and community support network for children to flourish in the future is our
 primary goal. A stretch goal for 2015 is to hold additional workshops 
for some of the young women who were former Kamlari, and who are now beginning to build their futures as independent adults. As they set out on their own and pursue their educational or 
career endeavors, they are the most vulnerable to falling back into the 
cycle of poverty, and we want to help ensure they receive additional 
support on their new path. 
(This excerpt from the Girl Rising documentary provides an accurate background on the Kamlari system in Nepal.)

A quote from Sunita's beautiful creative writing journal (shared with permission):"Believe in yourself! Have faith in your abilities! Without a humble but reasonable confidence in your own powers, you cannot be successful or happy."

  What We Need & What You Get We have an immediate goal, a stretch goal, and long-term goals for our project. Here's the breakdown and nitty gritty of each:

Immediate Goal: Our first objective is to return to Kathmandu to hold another workshop for the 30 teachers waiting for us. To do this, we need to raise $5,000 to cover expenses. This accounts for all expenses to hold three 10-person workshops including facility rental, materials and supplies. Every dollar donated directly supports this workshop, and the time loss away from our "normal work" to facilitate these events is our personal donation (i.e. we do not earn any income from holding these training workshops). There will be no fee to the school nor the teachers to participate, and we want to eliminate all other indirect costs, as well. In our 2014 workshop, funded by our own financial contribution, participants received all workshop materials and supplies (even pens and paper are expensive luxuries in Nepal!); meals and snacks were provided for three full days; clean bottled water was plentiful; and safe transportation to and from the meeting location was assured for each participant (most of whom were women). The average annual income in Nepal is less than $300 per year and does not adequately support a family's needs, so we also provided each participant with a stipend to help offset their lost wages for their three days in the workshop. All of the above will be provided again in 2015's workshops.


Stretch Goal: Raising an additional $1,500 allows us to broaden our reach and hold a fourth workshop specifically for young women who are ex-Kamlari.  Using the research and methodology of Dr. Brené Brown, in which Rob and Kristi are both certified, this workshop will support the girls in cultivating a courage practice and the shame resiliency skills that support their journey towards future life goals.

Longterm Project Goals: Once we have raised a total of $15,000, we will be able to accomplish all of the above, plus launch a self-sustaining fundraising model to continue annual workshops going forward, as well as beginning our new project--The Amai Program. Amai is the Nepali word for grandmother, and our project will partner local women with orphanages to create a community-supported cooperative effort that provides nurturance to orphaned children while creating meaningful work and fair wages for local women. More information about our project goals, including The Amai Program, can be found on our website.
PERKS!When you make the decision to contribute towards this project, the 
size of your generosity directly correlates with the number of people we
 are able to help. Here are the perks available to supporters of this project:
Perks from Nepal! We shopped at local vendors in Nepal who sell their handicrafts, and support fair labor for their crafters, to find some great gifts! Each item is unique and handmade; colors and details will vary.


Books and DVDs! In addition to these amazing Nepal handicrafts, you can learn more about the methodology we use in our workshops as well as the issues facing girls living in developing countries. Two of our favorites pieces of work are perks that will bring depth and knowledge of the work we are doing to donors who wish the engage more profoundly.


This Indiegogo campaign is set up to disperse all funds raised, even if we do not meet our full fundraising goal, because every dollar raised helps to make a difference in the continuation our work. In addition, perks are not dependent on meeting the total fundraising objective nor the campaign timelines, but will instead be sent at the time of your contribution, based upon the perk/donation level in which you choose to participate. 
The Indiegogo processing fees for this type of campaign are a bit higher than campaigns that must be fully funded within a timeline, so we understand that some individuals might choose to opt out of perks in order to have more of their contribution be used for program goals. If this is your preference, please just send us an email to let us know.
We will continue to fundraise through various channels until we meet our campaign goal. Even after this Indiegogo campaign ends, the opportunity to support this project in the future through one-time support or monthly ongoing support is explained on our website.
   
The Impact, Challenges & Risks
 Our first workshop in 2014 was truly a labor of love and faith. Nearly a year of pre-planning and curriculum development time was invested before we even arrived in Kathmandu. And, we went into the project with an awareness that we would encounter bumps.
Having never used our curriculum beyond a Western audience, we knew there would be work to bridge cultural, social and language barriers. And, there was. We knew that navigating the logistics of holding a workshop in Nepal would be challenging. And, it was. 
Because of our existing experience in Nepal, we were ready for teaching without reliable access to electricity, always without heat, with the daily chore of navigating congested dirt roads to our meeting location, with shooing away various farm animals along the way, and, most heartwarming, with making time in our busy teaching schedule to play with local kids and gain the trust of the community.

Now viewed as an extremely successful "pilot" project, our work in 2014 has enabled us to refine our curriculum and address particular regional topics in more depth. Additionally, we've built lasting relationships with supporters in Kathmandu who are ready to help us bring this work to more of the people who need it most. And while we are already very prepared for the challenges of this project, having strengthened our network in 2014 provides us with an additional level of support that only comes with community "buy in".Training teachers and social workers in our curriculum helps them to provide better support to the children with whom they work and to support the children's long-term development. Obstacles we may face as we expand this work are primarily in cultivating or deepening relationships with those in Kathmandu who can assist with these objectives.
In the months following the workshops, we believe it will be important to facilitate ongoing check-ins with the teachers who receive training in order to ensure that the ideas stick. We have developed a plan to accomplish this by using web-based teleconferencing. The obvious challenge is making the technology available to all who need it and maintaining participation when we are no longer physically in Nepal. We have verbal support of two Kathmandu organizations to help with this goal, and we will need to continue cultivating those relationships to ensure success.
Continuing our fundraising efforts will also be vitally important to ensure the project's continuation and growth. To address this, we have created the option for supporters to make one-time, as well as monthly, contributions on our website. We have also developed a marketing plan that we intend to be self-sustaining, and we plan to launch that campaign once our current fundraising objectives are met and allow us to invest in the materials needed for that endeavor.
   Other Ways You Can Help We know there are folks reading this who believe in the work we are trying to accomplish yet aren't able to make a financial contribution, but that doesn't mean you can't help. If you would like to help us further our project goals, here are some ways you can help:  
Help us to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign! This is the single biggest thing you can do to help us! Share this campaign page on your social media sites like Facebook, Twitter and anywhere else that you are connected. Email your friends and family. Chat up your neighbor. However you can spread the word, you will be making a big difference!


Ask for contributions to this campaign in lieu of birthday or special occasion gifts. The $50 spent on Valentine's candy and flowers that will only last a few days would make a big difference to this campaign! If just 100 people made this contribution, we would meet our first goal!


Sell something on eBay, Craigslist or Etsy, and contribute the money to this campaign. Get your friends to join you and hold a garage/yard sale!
If you think a little doesn't make a difference, think again! Use our website to make a monthly pledge. Over time, small contributions add up to big support!
 Use the Indiegogo share tools! Get the word out any way you can!

There are many, many worthy causes to support in the world. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you for considering the work we are trying to do!

story:
Short Summary

Each year, student-athletes at Missouri State pay close to $2,000 to play lacrosse. That money goes towards equipment, travel, facility usage and more. This fundraiser works towards the team's long term goal of eliminating out-of-pocket expense incurred by the players.

The Missouri State University Men's Lacrosse program is a full varsity Division II member of the Men's Collegiate Lacrosse Association (MCLA). We are hoping to raise money to build the program and further our goal of becoming an elite program in the MCLA. Raising this money will go great distances in helping us with travel, apparel, and equipment costs.

All donations are tax-deductible!

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $10,000 to help aid with the travel, apparel, and equipment costs of running an elite MCLA program.

  • If we reach our funding goals, the money will be used for bus and hotel fees. 
  • If we exceed our goals, the excess money will be used towards custom team apparel for our players.
  • Our perks include team apparel, signed game jerseys, personalized donor banners at Betty and Bobby Allison North Stadium, plus many more!
  • Our perks can be seen under the Gallery tab. 
  • If we do not meet our goal, we run the risk of not attaining the status of Elite MCLA program

The Impact

Men's Lacrosse at Missouri State is funded heavily through player dues and outside donors. Incoming freshman paid over $2,000 in yearly dues for 2015. By helping us reach our goal, you are allowing our student-athletes a chance to avoid further cost, as well as giving them an opportunity to focus on their lives as students.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Follow us on Twitter!
  • Like us on Facebook!
  • Come see us at a game!
  • Volunteer with the team!

Go BEARS!

story: After years of attempting to conduct his own independent archeological dig of the ancient wall in Rockwall,Texas. Josh Reeves is now on the cusp of doing just that. The goal is simple,dig out one or more sections of the wall and conduct a complete investigation documenting on film, every step of the process,in what may be the oldest civilization ever found. We have already secured excavation services and two possible dig sites,which has reduced the cost of doing a dig by 90 percent. This fundraiser will cover the miscellaneous expenses that will be necessary to conduct a full investigation including,full lab analysis of the material to be shown to the public,and any other services which may be needed to properly document ALL available information pertaining to the makeup of the wall's stone bricks and it's geo-polymer mortar.  It will also cover the production costs of the filming of the entire process which will be released as a full length documentary that we will be be entering into film festivals highlighting tales from Texas. Other expenses will include day to day operating costs of the investigation,including power generator rentals,water pumps,hand tools for digging etc.  We will also be the first excavation to go below 25 feet,almost 100 feet down to the bedrock in order to properly show what no one has ever seen,that the blocks get bigger the farther down you go! This will not be a made for tv whitewash,this investigation will show for the first time everything people have heard about the rockwall,(crystalline makeup,piezo electric ability etc) in order to allow this relic of the ancient past to have a proper day in court. This is your chance to make history and keep history from being written by the bad guys. We have already covered most of the cost but unforeseen events and circumstances have increased slightly due to the difficulty to obtain the dig sites. We are full steam ahead,help us go all the way!

story:
Our Story

My name is Antonia Alvarez and I am from Quito, Ecuador. I have been involved with the Galo Plaza Foundation for many years because it was founded by my great grandfather Galo Plaza, the past president of Ecuador. Galo Plaza was a true philanthropist. Gradually I have been falling in love with the community, the foundation and the people. The feeling I get every time I go to Zuleta is surreal because many children whom I have worked with call me by my name and greet me with enthusiasm. 

When I got an honor scholarship I felt as if I had won the lottery. Then is when I decided to donate the amount of my scholarship to a less privileged child of rural Ecuador. Suddenly I had a dream; it was to find a way to make it possible for most of the children in Zuleta to go to school. I was surprised to find out that with the amount of my scholarship I could pay for school for 33 children.

In order to get started with this project, I talked to some of my friends that also had been awarded with scholarships. Then is when Paulo Torres decided to join this campaign. We both donated, but we thought we could find more people to donate. Today, we are working together to fundraise $4,500 dollars to pay for school for 15 children in Zuleta.  

What We Need 

We only need to get people to donate. One full scholarship for one child for one year is worth $300.

Our goal is to reach $4,500. All the funds will go directly to the Galo Plaza Lasso Foundation to be used to pay for a child's education. The Galo Plaza Lasso Foundation has been running the same program; therefore, the procedure will be the same for our project. The foundation chooses the children who are the most needed based on information provided by the principal of the community's school. The foundation has strong ties with the school and it will assure that the most vulnerable children get access to education. 

What You Get 

The person that makes the most generous donation will receive a free night for two people at the Hacienda Zuleta Hotel (http://zuleta.com). 

The second most generous donor will receive a collection of custom made perfumes of my brand, "Quinta Esencia."  

Everyone who donates is welcome to visit Hacienda Zuleta and the foundation to meet the community. If you come to Zuleta you get first choice to volunteer at the Galo Plaza Foundation. 

We will also make sure that you get an update of how the child you supported is doing in school.    

The Impact

With Paulo's donation and mine we will finance one school year for 66 children. Additionally, if we reach our goal 15 more children will be benefited. A total of 81 children would get a full scholarship for the coming school year of 2015-2016. If there are less than 81 children that need financial aid, the money will be saved in the foundation's fund to finance the following school year of the most needed. 

Risks and Challenges 

We are prepared to face any challenges that come in the way. The Galo Plaza Lasso Foundation's director has vast experience with social work in the community and she will help us through the process of selecting the children and assuring that the funds are well administrated. 

The biggest risk involved in donating a scholarship is that the children that receive scholarships live under very critical conditions. Therefore, they are the most vulnerable to drop out of school and the money would be lost if we cannot find another child to take his or her place.      

I know a child, Ismael, who has received a scholarship for 5 consecutive years and he has made the most out of it. He participates in many extracurricular activities, takes advantage of tutoring and has good grades. Despite all the barriers that prevent him from going to school such as the fact that he has to take care of his siblings, cook for the family and look after the animals, he is successful.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Visit the foundation's website (http://fundaciongaloplazalasso.org/en/ ) and become a volunteer.

Contact (antoniaalvarezuribe@hotmail.com) and buy "Quinta Esencia" perfumes/colognes. 

Help us raise awareness to reach our goal.

story:
Hello,
We are the San Jose State University Design/Build/Fly (DBF) Team. We are a team of 12 and counting aerospace engineering students hoping to raise funds to compete in the AIAA DBF competition in Tuscon, AZ in April, 2015. 

Since we currently have no corporate sponsorship or academic funding, we need your support to help us get to Arizona. We estimate that it will cost around $6,000 to pay for materials, build and test prototypes, come up with a final design, and travel to the competition.

We believe this competition is a valuable learning experience that provides hands-on experience in designing and building an aircraft from the ground up. With this experience we will be able to graduate and enter the aerospace industry as better engineers and valuable members of the teams we join.

There is no donation too small and those of you who can't contribute financially can still greatly help us by spreading the word.

Thank you for taking the time to view our fundraiser!

-SJSU DBF Team

Click here to find out more 'About Us'

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Neil Trigger. I'm a law student from Plymouth, but I'm not like the others.

The legal profession is incredibly competitive and pretty elitist, with a large number of solicitors being Oxbridge graduates with a lot of money. I'm not.

Before university, I wrote to 57 web development companies asking for a job (that's what my first career was) but they all wanted me to get a degree to prove I could do it. I went to university, got a 1st and applied again (and more besides). The credit crunch bit so I was jobless, so I went to work creating a publishing company and latterly working in a callcentre to fund it. For a time, it was a great success, garnering international acclaim and selling in national book stores, but a number of bad investments and business deals meant me having to invest all of my savings to keep it afloat and eventually I closed it. This led me to the brink of a mental breakdown and significant heartache.

While on leave from my callcentre job, I applied for the law course, thinking that I could work in the evenings and do the course during the day. Sadly as this is effectively a 3 year degree in one year, it's intense and there is no time to work full-time. I therefore have to fit in website development jobs to help fund myself and my family.

  • This course will help me turn around the fortunes of my entire family, including two of the sweetest children who have only had one holiday in ten years.
  • I'm already achieving awards for best legal argument, best advocacy skills and won a beautiful trophy in the client interviewing competition, but all of this will be worthless without your support to keep me on the course.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I have paid what I can and will continue to do so, but I still need around £4,000 for course fees and materials
  • I have experience in publishing and can help you get published.
  • I have been a professional magician and can show you some astonishing tricks that you can perform to your friends and family
  • I can help you with your legal queries, draft contracts and offer guidance on legal matters.
  • If I do not reach my goal, the funds will go entirely to help paying off my course fees and securing a stable career.

The Impact

  • Everyone needs legal representation at some point in their life - whether this is simply a conveyance for a house, an employment contract or even something a little more serious.
  • By including me in the legal profession, I will be able to make it more approachable, more human and more identifiable with the average person.
  • I am a great student who is already achieving good grades and winning awards.
  • All I need is the money to make it happen.

Risks & Challenges

It's an intense course, but I have the time management and tenacity skills to ensure I succeed.

  • It is difficult to assimilate all of the legal knowledge into one head, but I have developed a good system of revision and neumonics to help me.
  • Graduates from this course require a lot of work experience which means that students don't have enough time to work another job to fund their course. This filters poorer students away from this kind of occupation. I have secured work experience with two firms, but this does mean that I need your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. 

  • If you feel passionately about this campaign then get the message out there, spread the word on social media and tell your friends.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

While on leave from my callcentre job, I applied for the law course, thinking that I could work in the evenings and do the course during the day. Sadly as this is effectively a 3 year degree in one year, it's intense and there is no time to work full-time. I therefore have to fit in website development jobs to help fund myself and my family.
 This course will help me turn around the fortunes of my entire family, including two of the sweetest children who have only had one holiday in ten years. I'm already achieving awards for best legal argument, best advocacy skills and won a beautiful trophy in the client interviewing competition, but all of this will be worthless without your support to keep me on the course.
   What We Need & What You Get  I have paid what I can and will continue to do so, but I still need around £4,000 for course fees and materials I have experience in publishing and can help you get published.
I have been a professional magician and can show you some astonishing tricks that you can perform to your friends and family
I can help you with your legal queries, draft contracts and offer guidance on legal matters. If I do not reach my goal, the funds will go entirely to help paying off my course fees and securing a stable career.    The Impact  Everyone needs legal representation at some point in their life - whether this is simply a conveyance for a house, an employment contract or even something a little more serious.
By including me in the legal profession, I will be able to make it more approachable, more human and more identifiable with the average person. I am a great student who is already achieving good grades and winning awards.
All I need is the money to make it happen.    Risks & Challenges  It's an intense course, but I have the time management and tenacity skills to ensure I succeed.  It is difficult to assimilate all of the legal knowledge into one head, but I have developed a good system of revision and neumonics to help me.
Graduates from this course require a lot of work experience which means that students don't have enough time to work another job to fund their course. This filters poorer students away from this kind of occupation. I have secured work experience with two firms, but this does mean that I need your support.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.   If you feel passionately about this campaign then get the message out there, spread the word on social media and tell your friends. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Thousands of children in Cape Town are 
living in dire circumstances.

****    ****    ****

People working with children find themselves isolated, 
under-resourced and inadequately trained. 
Our network of child protection advocates are 
committed to improving the situation of 
children at risk in South Africa.

****    ****    ****

Connect Network 

is a collaboration of dedicated people 

working with children at risk 

in South Africa.  

****    ****    ****

WHAT WE DO
Focusing on the whole life-cycle of vulnerable children:
1. We bring together viable and active charities in South Africa so that  they have a stronger and wider impact in their communities.
2. We help protect and nurture thousands of children through synergies, collaboration and networking.
3. We help develop caregivers so that they can thrive in their work. 
4. We provide interactive skills-training and pooling of resources.


****    ****    ****

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO RAISE

$10 000.00 

BY 10 June  2015


THESE FUNDS WILL EQUIP 

OVER ONE HUNDRED CHILD ADVOCATES

TO ENSURE THE SAFEGUARDING 

OF CHILDREN IN THEIR CARE.


****    ****    ****

THE TEAM
Our  team of network specialists work with and support child advocates  who work in the worst at-risk areas, we also represent them on issues that affect children  by  engaging with government and other stakeholders.


             


Dee Moskoff:  Director of Connect Network. Qualified Nurse (Pediatric primary health care) and Midwife.  Completing a Master's in Public Administration . Her vision is to see the public integrity and advancement of small-to-medium sized Civil Society Organizations by their providing quality maternal and child welfare to those in need, and by these CSOs being seen as credible, significant and respected peer-contributors in the field of local, regional & global development.
Priscilla Muller: Office Administrator at Connect Network. Priscilla provides  hospitality for meetings, managing our reception, welcoming visitors, and ensuring that our resources are in good order. She is a great support to the programme and to our finance administration dept.
Beverley Stoffberg:  Finance Manager at Connect Network. A qualified Chartered Accountant (CA) Beverley is keen to see Non-Profit Organizations become financially sustainable in the long-term, and well-run fiscally. She believes in empowering disadvantaged women to be skilled in book-keeping to make them job ready. 
Linda Walters: Community Co-ordinator at Connect Network. Linda's extensive experience in working with grass-roots organizations in Cape Town's poverty-stricken areas qualifies her as a specialist in community development. Her role is to develop relationships among our network members and to encourage struggling organizations through their crises.

****     ****    ****

CONNECT NETWORK HAS BEEN IN OPERATION SINCE 2004 AND SERVES MORE THAN 200 000 CHILDREN A YEAR THROUGH OUR 108 NPO'S. 

CONNECT NETWORK PARTNERS WITH VIVA NORTH AMERICA. 

****    ****    ****

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, you can help by:

  • Getting the word out to friends who you think can help us - so share this link.
  • Sign our child protection petition to help us advocate to the South African government to increase its role in protection children click here

story:
Growing Hope in Haiti


The Solidarity School in Tremesse is in the Northwest coast of Haiti near Cap Haitien. It is located in a very rural part of Haiti where many of the children are the first to attend any school in their family. Our goal is to develop creative thinkers who can solve many of Haiti's problems. We purposely started with an elementary school to develop the programs to achieve this. We have learned that the Haitian text books are woefully behind and, as many U.S. school systems have found, the best education contains the interaction with the internet and laptops.

We have just installed the microwave internet system and now we need the laptops. We will start with 20 simple laptop units and have a computer lab where the children can work on internet based science and math programs and have  special after school programs where the children can collaborate on projects that can help them understand and solve some of Haiti's greatest challenges.  We currently have 250 students and 12 certified teachers. Visit our web site at  www.handsforhaiti.org.


Hands For Haiti is a registered non profit 501 3(c) organization that provides education, meals, clean water, and heath exams for our students and has been operating for 8 years. Please help us by supporting children in the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. Hands For Haiti is a true non profit- everyone is a volunteer who pays for there own expenses.


Mark Creasser- Hands For Haiti
3600 Exbury Gardens Drive, Waxhaw, NC 28173
Cell 704-634-0325

story:
Short Summary

Not a lot of good news comes out of Nigeria, Africa's largest democracy with 180mm citizens. Corruption, crime, and violence there are the results of poverty, weak character, and hopelessness. I believe that if you can help change the Nigerian youth, who by the way want a better life!, by installing in them hard work, ethics and giving them the opportunity to put those values to work then you get kids, and therefore, an entire country better able to show the world integrity, leadership, and prosperity.

My name is Adam Miles and over 10 years ago I started a humanitarian startup called Bridges To America to help give Africans the financial lift they need to help them fulfill their potential in the world. 

Three years ago, with my 12 year-old daughter, Kylie, and with a lot of help from family and friends, we married this desire to help Africans help themselves with the world's sport of soccer and launched Save-A-Thon For Africa. (You can check out our website here.)

Today we are very active in Nigeria, where over 100mm people live on less than $1.00 a day. In the next three years we will build the Bridges Soccer & Business Academy to provide a word class platform to teach and build the youth in Nigeria.

As a critical part of this effort we are in the middle of running our unique and exciting program, Save-A-Thon For Africa. We conduct free soccer clinics then invite local teams to play in our Bridges Cup, which we host. The winning boys and girls teams of the Cup then get the chance to visit the USA to play against American kids and visit our schools and businesses.  

One of the coolest thing about our progam is that we engage American young women soccer players to travel with us to Nigeria and engage, motivate, and challenge the youth through soccer.

I LOVE what we are doing! I have dedicated my life, and a significant chunk of my family's financial and emotional capital to get us to where we are today. But I need you to help me and my team take the next step and conclude the Bridges Cup Finals we started last November.

Everyone talks about change and saving the world. We aren't big and we don't know everything but we are passionate about doing what we can to touch lives one person at a time.

I hope you'll take a minute and join us as we save lives by changing futures.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $25,000 to put on the Bridges Cup Finals in Lagos on May 9th, 2015.

The money will be used for the following expenses related to the Cup:
  • Venue and officials
  • Transportation & Lodging for 4 youth teams from their villages to Lagos
  • Transportation on the ground in Lagos for US soccer team volunteers
  • Security for the Americans and matches
  • Awards and Gifts for participants and fans
We are thrilled to be working with members of Utah's semi-pro women's soccer team affiliated with the MLS team: Real Salt Lake.
If for some reason we don't raise the full $25,000 we will use whatever funds we do raise to make an impact on the tournament. This campaign is all about keeping promises and every dollar we raise will enable us to better give these Nigerian kids the chance of a lifetime to reach their full potential.
I have never believed in getting something for nothing so we are delighted to offer some one-of-a-kind perks to our supporters.
Because we are working with the players from Real Salt Lake Women we have connections to these amazing women and their former teammates and friends in the NWSL and on the US Women's National Team. These ladies love our mission and are working hard to help us make it happen. Check these out!
  • One-on-one training session
  • Autographed apparel, soccer stuff
  • eBook of We Are One
  • Trip to Canada to watch the US Women's team play Nigeria in the World Cup
  • Limited design T-Shirts
  • And more!

The Impact

I love to say, because it's true, that it takes SO little to do SO much in Africa. Unless and until you have been there this may sound trite but when you consider that 100mm Nigerians live on less than $1 a day this saying may actually mean something to you. These kids have very little and their leaders let them down regularly. You have the chance with this very campaign to DO SOMETHING to positively impact these kids. Not to mention the way these funds will help our American player volunteers get to Lagos and change lives.

Check out our website for the media coverage and hundreds of photos of past trips. Buy our eBook to read the kind of change you can help make happen.
Look at what we've done and help us do more. This is going to be amazing!

Risks & Challenges

Nothing in Nigeria is easy, except the smiles of the youth you see there, and this project has risks. The Presidential election is just concluding and it is too early to say there will be no post-election turmoil. We will not put our team or these kids there at risk if it is not safe to visit Nigeria in early May. But, I have personally traveled there more than 10 times over the past 18 months now without incident and I am confident that we will be safe and able to execute our plan. If, for some reason, we are unable to put on the Cup in May as planned we will simply reschedule for a later date this year when things settle down.
Further, should our fundraising not go as planned and we fall short we will continue to work relentlessly to find the funding we need to keep the promises to these kids and hold the Cup. I have done it before and I know we can do it again.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to our campaign we would love your help in simply making some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks!

story:
This is the story of 13 Israeli kids who have been meeting and organizing, and stopping nothing short of breaking records in Israel, as well as achieving personal goals for themselves in the area of robotics.

This year the team's research project focused on ways to make the physical classroom environment more suitable for learning with the use of new technology and layout of the classroom.  The team designed a classroom that will be built next year in their own school in Modiin and the Kipa Bots were invited to meet with the head of the Education Ministry in Israel to share these innovative ideas and research.  

This research project was part of what led them to win a championship prize at the National Israeli competition in March of 2015, earning them an invitation to represent Israel in the world tournament in South Africa in May of 2015.

This is an extraordinary group of kids.

This is a group who has spent most afternoons and evenings meeting and organizing, writing and revising, designing and programming, brainstorming and collaborating, and mastering the important life skill of working together as a group to be the successful team that they are.

This is an ambitious group too; the Kipa Bots team is busy working to be change makers where they can lend a hand in the community.  How? Each team member has made a personal commitment to:

1. Volunteering and sharing the wonder of robotics with at-risk children

2. Collect and donate school supplies to a local children's organization

3. Collect canned foods to donate to a homeless shelter in Tel Aviv

We need your help to raise the remaining funds to go to South Africa and represent the state of Israel at the upcoming tournament.  

We hope you can help.

Postscript:  On May 7th, the KipaBots were honored to win 2nd place in the overall  FLL competition in South Africa.  Congratulations!

story:
We are partnering with Indiegogo in our world-wide campaign to introduce meditation to young children to calm aggression and anger while at the same time reinforcing positive emotions and behavior.

We want to make meditation for children fun and inspiring.

Your contributions will help us to develop our Karma Kyle the Crocodile books, animation videos and other products for kids ages 3 and up.


Our Inspirational Story


It all started a few years ago when a very close person sent me a quote by the Dalai Lama:

“If every child in the world would be taught meditation, we would eliminate violence in the world within one generation”


I thought to myself, could this really be possible?

My first reaction was that the world has battled with war and violence since the dawn of time and there is no way that is going to change.

But where do all these problems and acts of violence stem from?  The mind.

The mind, as we all know, is a very powerful thing.

….an untrained mind can be dangerous and damaging to others.  It overreacts, it is overrun with emotions, it often says things without thinking about consequences and initiates acts that we often find incomprehensible.

.....but a trained mind through meditation can positively change the way we think, what we say and how we act.

I have worked as a naturopathic doctor for more than 20 years, dealing with natural means to heal the mind, body and spirit and having practiced meditation for years, it has become clear to me that if we want to make peace in the world and achieve the health and happiness that we all deserve, we have to start with ourselves, especially our children and of most importance our minds.

               



Who is Karma Kyle the Crocodile?



To motivate us to do something positive, we need a reason and often we need a role model, someone we can relate to and look up to and follow.

Even children.

So, although maybe seen as an unlikely guru or role model for young children,  the Karma Kyle the Crocodile  cartoon character was born. The first meditating crocodile in the world.

….but come to think of it, what better animal character than the often perceived fierce, cruel, ruthless crocodile could be a more worthy contender for needing meditation practice?


Karma Kyle is a little boy crocodile, who like any other typical child, is always pushing the limits and getting into trouble. Thank goodness he has his meditating family to keep him in line. Throughout his adventures, Karma Kyle deals with greed, jealousy, anger and a host of other negative emotions and often through the hard way, learns that bad deeds always lead to a bad ending (hence karma), and that meditation and positive emotions will always help to get you back on the right track.


Meet the Karma Crocodile Family:


Meet some of the Bad Guys:

      

Meet a very unusually talented elephant:                 

and a very Wise Owl:

                                     


Why your involvement is so important


We want you to play an important part in the beginning of a world-wide campaign to educate and introduce meditation to young children to calm manage negative emotions such as aggression, fear and anger while at the same time reinforcing positive emotions and behavior.

We want to make meditation for children fun and inspiring through our Karma Kyle the Crocodile books, animation videos and other products.

Meditation for young children has been found to greatly benefit:

·  Concentration and performance at school

·  Memory

·  Insomnia and stress

·  Management of anger, aggression and temper tantrums

·  Hyperactivity

·  Bullying

·  ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder)

Here is a great video, showing the power of meditation for chldren, interviewing kids before and after meditation who have ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder)


Please also read this article about studies on the positive effects of meditation on young children:

Click here to read the article


What we have accomplished so far:

We have used our own funds to do the following already:

1. written and illustrated books in the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series
  (see samples of the books below) with ideas for many more books

From the book,"Karmy Kyle the Crocodile: Angry Clouds" which teaches children how to deal with anger through meditation and self-reflection. (32 color illustrated pages with rhyming text)

From the book,"Karmy Kyle the Crocodile: Friendship is the Greatest Treasure"
which teaches children about overcoming greed with meditation and the value of friendship. (32 color illustrated pages with rhyming text)


2.   registered Karma Kyle the Crocodile as a trademark

3.  worked with an animation company on producing a rough promo animation video for Karma Kyle the Crocodile  

4. written and recorded the Karma Kyle the Crocodile theme song with a group of kid singers

5. we have a team of very talented animators and illustrators ready to get started but..........

We need your financial help to continue......


With your contributions, we will use the funds to:

 

                                            

1.  Market, develop, print and distribute books in the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series (we have already some books in the series prepared)

2.  Bring Karma Kyle the Crocodile to life in his own animated videos for web and TV that will inspire young children around the world. (We are working with an animation company and with your help we will produce an animated cartoon pilot based on the books.

 3. Produce an animated guided meditation video that will teach young children to meditate and transform negative emotions to positive behavior along with Karma Kyle the Crocodile and other characters in the series.

4. Develop and produce a line of Karma Kyle the Crocodile meditation 

  products for children including meditation pillows, mats and clothing


Stretch Goals: If we surpass our target and reach a goal of over 100,OOO dollars, our passion and commitment will not stop as,

1. We will then produce a Karma Kyle the Crocodile musical meditation CD for children.

2. We will produce two more animated cartoon videos based on the books.

3. We want to bring Karma Kyle the Crocodile to meditation workshops combined with children’s theatre, where parents can actively participate in meditation with their children while seeing their favorite characters perform from the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series.

4. We will translate some of the books and videos into other languages, including Spanish, French and German.


What Karma Kyle Perks can You Get


1O dollars gets you a personal thank you by email PLUS we will send you  a downloadable  illustrated printable poster of the entire Karma Crocodile family meditating, PLUS you will have the comfort of knowing that  for every 10 contributions of 10 dollars, we will donate and send a paperback copy of Karma Kyle the Crocodile - Friendship is the Greatest Treasure  to a child in need.


   Poster

We promise to keep you posted!

Join us, be a part of the beginning

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help financially, you can also help by spreading the word through your social media channels, tell your friends and family, help spread the word about Karma Kyle the Crocodile and the value of meditation for children!  If you need a fundraiser product for your fundraising campaign, we can provide Karma Kyle the Crocodile books and products.

Thank you so much!

Frank Navratil (Creator) and the team at Karma Kyle Productions
story_txt:
We are partnering with Indiegogo in our world-wide campaign to introduce
meditation to young children to calm aggression and anger while at the same time reinforcing positive
emotions and behavior. 
We want to make
meditation for children fun and inspiring.
 Your contributions will help us to develop our Karma Kyle the Crocodile books, animation videos and other products for kids ages 3 and up.



Our Inspirational Story
It all started a few
years ago when a very close person sent me a quote by the Dalai Lama:“If every child in the world would be taught
meditation, we would eliminate violence in the world within one generation”

I thought to myself,
could this really be possible? 
My first reaction was
that the world has battled with war and violence since the dawn of time and there
is no way that is going to change.
But where do all
these problems and acts of violence stem from?  The mind.
The mind, as we all
know, is a very powerful thing.
….an untrained mind
can be dangerous and damaging to others. 
It overreacts, it is overrun with emotions, it often says things without
thinking about consequences and initiates acts that we often find
incomprehensible.
.....but a trained mind through
meditation can positively change the way we think, what we say and how we act.
I have worked as a naturopathic doctor for more than 20 years, dealing with natural means to heal the mind, body and spirit and having practiced meditation for years, it has become clear to me
that if we want to make peace in the world and achieve the health and happiness that we all deserve, we have to start with ourselves, especially
our children and of most importance our minds. 

                

Who is Karma Kyle the Crocodile?


To motivate us to do
something positive, we need a reason and often we need a role model, someone we
can relate to and look up to and follow.

Even children.
So, although maybe
seen as an unlikely guru or role model for young children,  the Karma Kyle the Crocodile  cartoon character was born. The
first meditating crocodile in the world.
….but come to think
of it, what better animal character than the often perceived fierce, cruel, ruthless crocodile
could be a more worthy contender for needing meditation practice?


Karma Kyle is a little
boy crocodile, who like any other typical child, is always pushing the limits
and getting into trouble. Thank goodness he has his meditating family to keep
him in line. Throughout his adventures, Karma Kyle deals with greed, jealousy,
anger and a host of other negative emotions and often through the hard way,
learns that bad deeds always lead to a bad ending (hence karma), and that meditation
and positive emotions will always help to get you back on the right track.

Meet the Karma Crocodile Family:

Meet some of the Bad Guys:
       



Meet a very unusually talented elephant:                  





and a very Wise Owl:

                                      
Why your involvement is so important

We want you to play an
important part in the beginning of a world-wide campaign to educate and introduce
meditation to young children to calm manage negative emotions such as aggression, fear and anger while at the same time reinforcing positive
emotions and behavior.We want to make
meditation for children fun and inspiring through our Karma Kyle the Crocodile books, animation videos and other products.
Meditation for young children
has been found to greatly benefit:· 
Concentration
and performance at school
·  Memory
·  Insomnia and stress
· 
Management
of anger, aggression and temper tantrums 
· 
Hyperactivity
· 
Bullying
·  ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder)
Here is a great video, showing the power of meditation for chldren,  interviewing kids before and after meditation who have ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder)




Please also read this article about studies on the positive effects of meditation on young children:
Click here to read the article

What we have accomplished so far:
We have used our own funds to do the following already:
1. written and
illustrated books in the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series  (see samples of the books below) with ideas for many more booksFrom the book,"Karmy Kyle the Crocodile: Angry Clouds" which teaches children how to deal with anger through meditation and self-reflection. (32 color illustrated pages with rhyming text)
 From the book,"Karmy Kyle the Crocodile: Friendship is the Greatest Treasure"which teaches children about overcoming greed with meditation and the value of friendship. (32 color illustrated pages with rhyming text)
2.  
registered Karma Kyle the Crocodile as a trademark
3.  worked
with an animation company on producing a rough promo animation video for Karma Kyle the
Crocodile   
4. written
and recorded the Karma Kyle the Crocodile theme song with a group of kid
singers 
5. we have a team of very talented animators and illustrators ready to get started but..........
We need your financial help to continue......



With your contributions, we will use the funds to:

  
                                             1.  Market,
develop, print and distribute books in the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series (we have already some books in the series prepared)2.  Bring
Karma Kyle the Crocodile to life in his own animated videos for web and TV that will inspire young children around the world. (We are working with an animation company and with your help we will produce an animated cartoon pilot based on the books.
 3. Produce
an animated guided meditation video that will teach young children to meditate and transform negative emotions to positive behavior along with Karma Kyle the Crocodile and other characters in the series.
4. Develop
and produce a line of Karma Kyle the Crocodile meditation  
  products for children including meditation
pillows, mats and clothing
Stretch Goals: If we surpass our target and reach a goal of over 100,OOO dollars, our passion and commitment will not stop as,
1. We will
then produce a Karma Kyle the Crocodile musical meditation CD for children.
2. We will produce two more animated cartoon videos based on the books.
3. We
want to bring Karma Kyle the Crocodile to meditation workshops combined with children’s theatre, where parents can
actively participate in meditation with their children while seeing their
favorite characters perform from the Karma Kyle the Crocodile series.
4. We will translate some of the books and videos into other languages, including Spanish, French and German.

  What Karma Kyle Perks can You Get




1O dollars gets you a personal thank you by email PLUS we will send you  a downloadable  illustrated printable poster of the entire Karma Crocodile family meditating, PLUS you will have the comfort of knowing that  for every 10 contributions of 10 dollars, we will donate and send a paperback copy of Karma Kyle the Crocodile - Friendship is the Greatest Treasure  to a child in need.

story:
We the team of Outfitter Nepal, our guides and all the staff are the affected by the Earthquake of 25th Apr, 2015 and all our homes, our staff homes and the villager’s homes and many of the schools around us are collapsed so, we have started this campaign to raise some fund to provide some relief to the victims of the area, to help our staff to build their shelters and to support to built school in the area:

The Shree Chakreshwari Lower Secondary School :

Appeal to all from the Head teacher of the School:


Shree Chakreshwari Lower Secondary School : is located at Tripureshwar 06, Dhading, Nepal; where there are about 400 students are studying now from grade 01 to 08. All the building are collapsed from the Earthquake on the 25thApril, 2015 and I (Arjun Rijal) am just returned from the village and I visited the school as well there is not any possibilities for the children to study in this School for now, I could not do anything as it cost lot of money to re-build those building rather than just looking at them without any words. Now we have estlablish a fund to raise of 50,000.00USD to provide some relief material, to support to our staff and to support the school building - we need your support for this work, we would cordially welcome to all the individual, clubs, schools, collages, NGOS, INGOS or any personnel and Organizations to join for our project and we have target to raise 50, 00000.00 (Fifty Lakhs Rupees) - 50,000.00 (Approx. fifty thousand American dollar and we appeal to all of you to contribute by little as you can , please ,we will never forget your support in this difficult situation we are facing now in Nepal:

Where the fund goes:

The money we raise from this will spend to provide relief material in the affected area ( Tripureshwar, Dhading), to built home of our staff and for the Shree Chakreshwari Lower Secondary School :

Providing some relief to the victims of the Area:

About The Founder

I am one of the founders of Outfitter Nepal Treks Expedition PVT. LTD. which was established in 2008, born in Dhading, Nepal (A remote part of Nepal that lies North West of Kathmandu). I have completed his graduation in Tourism Sociology from Tribhubhan University, Katmandu, Nepal.

I am committed to complete this project and hope, to have the support from all of you:

The classrooms of the school

Why for School:

We will distribute relief materials for the villagers around us in the area which in not enough however some individuals , government agencies , NGOS and INGOS are providing some relief for the victims of the area as well and  not any one yet have plan to re-build this school which has lost all the building from this disaster and there is any building/place left to start the class now, people are looking relief for themselves since all of them are victims – and I see that the class will not start and we are not sure about the future for the 400 students those currently studying there:


The Administration office of the School

So, we have started to raise some fund for this project with the hopeful to all the people around the world who can contribute little for this good work:

We would like request you to make a donation to any of the funds for this project which goes directly to the construction of this school and me and the my team are always ready volunteers do all the admin works to complete this project.

Thank you very much for your support!

story:
Hello I am Rolo and I am Autistic. I would like to talk to you about a new social venture I am starting called AutismRolo.

I have OCD and Acute Anxiety Disorder and want to use my past experiences to improve your understanding of what it’s like to live with Autism in the UK.

I believe Austistic people have a positive  and important contribution to make in our communities and with some simple changes to both our built environment and our behaviour towards autism, we can transform the lives of Autistics and create a more productive society for us all.

I am in the process of converting a 1997 Ford Transit van into the AutismRolo tour bus. In Autumn 2015 I intend to travel the UK, offering free and paid for events to help individuals, groups and oganisations to work together, solve problems and inspire positive change. 

Where is your money going?

Insulating the van adding swivel chairs and an awning to give talks in the shade or out of the rain.
Gas electrics  require registered  installation,and a new fridge. Autism friendly lighting ,fuel and running costs, tax, insurance MOT and business startup costs

A converted van is a necessity because as an autistic I am severely affected by sensory stimulus,have a spinal condition and after giving my time to people need a safe environment to recoup and rest  A van would serve as a mini office and enable me to travel further afield, sleep overnight and get to places and people that live in out of the way locations. 

Extra money would also pay for teaching tools information and signboards fuel and any  additional costs

To date there are almost no post diagnostic services for adults diagnosed with ASC autism spectrum condition; I know this because I am one of them. I am working tirelessly to rectify this whilst tackling the stigma and discrimination in the way that Autism is percieved and excluded.

My passion and mission is to get on the road and start a conversation from an autistic perspective highlighting the huge talent pool that is going to waste due to the fear and misunderstanding of our neurodiversity.  I aim to bridge the divide between us all and to celebrate differences, combining all our talents (both autistic and non autistic)which will serve to create a better neurodiverse society built on tolerance, understanding, knowledge and cooperation.

I will be able to achieve this by

▪ Giving talks and to other Autism charities whilst assisting in their training which I already do on a voluntary basis

▪ Providing talks seminars, workshops and training in both the public and private sectors

 ▪ Visiting businesses large and small to encourage and promote employment of Autistic workers whilst providing practical solutions (only 15% of those diagnosed are in gainful employment)

▪ Attending Autism Conferences nationally

▪ Setting up flash workshops in public spaces

Lobbying for change

Our long term ambition is to change the way decisions are made at the
top and to help policy makers create a more productive inclusive society.
I believe we can avoid costly mistakes, saving time and money, improving experiences and enhancing all our lives

▪ Addressing mental health issues which means providing advise for both autistics and non autistic ( 1 in 3 of us will experience mental health issues at some point in our lives and the stigma surrounding this subject in 2015 is still problematic)

All help advice and support in any form would be hugely appreciated by AutismRolo

story:
Cocktail Chronicles mission is to inform and educate consumers on wine, spirits, beers, and non-alcoholic beverages.  Providing knowledge to assist consumers in being confident, smart, aware, and responsible in their cocktail and beverage selections. 

In order to be successful in this venture I need to garner $5,000.  These funds will be utilized to support photographic and video cameras.  If I don't reach my full goal, the funds will be used to purchased used equipment. 

To authentically report the behind the scene news of liquor manufacturers and to empower consumers with education, the proper equipment and assistance is needed.  It's our goal to solicit advertisement and sponsorship opportunities.  

If you can't assist with the campaign, be sure to visit the site and share your cocktail experience.    

In today's society people invest a lot into their leisure time. Often times they are seeking cozy intimate environments to meet friends, other singles, co-workers, or business clients to escape their everyday environments to loosen up and relax. In which, the first question you’re asked at an establishment is, “what can I start you off with to drink”.  Cocktail Chronicles will provide you with the knowledge to make your drink order confidently; the language to engage in dialogue with your peers that are wine/beer/spirits connoisseurs; and perhaps the initiative to try a cocktail out of the ordinary for your pallet.

Je’ Wesley has over 15 years of experience in working in the bar and restaurant industry.  Having worked from restaurants in Chicago, to the nightclubs of New York City, then opening his own restaurant/bar in Atlanta, Georgia in 2013.  Je’ also has a passion for journalism and marketing having received a Bachelor’s Degree in Communications from Northern Illinois University, a MBA in Marketing from Keller Graduate School of Management, and a current Doctoral of Education Student at Argosy University. 

It’s Je’ Wesley’s goal to combine his passions for the spirits and journalism industries and couple it with his thirst for continuous education by providing consumers with the online digital media website of “Cocktail Chronicles”.  Cocktail Chronicles mission is to inform and educate consumers on wine, spirits, beers, and non-alcoholic beverages.  Providing knowledge to assist consumers in being confident, smart, aware, and responsible in their cocktail and beverage selections.

Je’ Wesley is no stranger to leadership as he has presided over local organizations such as Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Incorporated (both undergraduate and graduate levels), NAACP, Young Democrats of Illinois, and the former Community Relations Chairman for the Atlanta Association of Black Journalists (AABJ). He is currently a member of the AABJ, United States Bartenders Guild, the Georgia Restaurant Association, National Black MBA Association and Atlanta’s Buckhead Toastmasters Club.

To garnish his academic and leadership credentials Je’ Wesley has earned the following certifications:

·  Wine Certification

·  Mixology Certification

·  Georgia’s SafeServ Certification

Turn to the expert, Je’ Wesley and Cocktail Chronicles for your knowledge on cocktails.  Read reviews on handcrafted drinks, learn the best places to go for great drinks under $21 in your major cities, and even retrieve crafty drink recipes to try at home and much more at www.cocktailchron.com .
