story:
Hello, I'm Mandy, I run the  The Good Samaritan Foundation of Haiti - a small donor-funded charity working in 2 parts of rural Haiti. Our main work over the last 5 years has been in building and operating two FREE primary schools that educate and feed 500 children ages 3 to 18. 

However, we recognize the urgent need for more advanced skills and higher education for our communities - so we started a scholarship program for high-school, trade school and university.  As we go into the third year we already have two graduates, Jude serving as our 5th grade teacher, and our agriculture manager Anousse, who both live on Ile a Vache  working for our foundation and the community - enabling others to learn from their knowledge and bringing new ideas and trade-able skills.

Anousse, recent graduate and agricultural manager. Top picture, far left is Jude, our 5th grade teacher in the new School in Le Hatte.

We are striving really hard to keep the success growing and this is where your help is much needed. 

Unfortunately this year we have found ourselves without the funds to sustain our commitment to our 4  under-graduates.  

We have to raise essential funds to cover four scholarships which pay for the students' tuition, lodging and a small daily stipend (under $5) that covers food, books, and transport. A one year scholarship starts at under $4000 per student.

School starts next month and we urgently need to provide funding so that students can complete their current years, and move into accomplished roles that positively impact their immediate and wider community.

Students needing this crucial support are:

Carline - last year of nursing diploma $3600
Adeline - 3rd year of 4 in advanced nursing degree $3750
Daniel - 3rd year of 5 in agriculture science $3750
Pouchon - 2nd year of 5 in civil engineering. $3900


The current students are all committed to staying in their villages on Ile a Vache and helping advance the community when they graduate.

Carline - Nursing Diploma

I was born in La Hatte on Ile a Vache and I am the youngest of 6 siblings. My father is a fisherman and my mother was a small trader but she sadly died seven years ago at which point I had to leave my secondary school, and my home on Ile a Vache to go and live with my god-mother on the mainland to finish school. I focused on my studies gaining my Baccalaureat in 2012, when I was the only girl in my village to complete high school. 

I have always wanted to become a nurse and thanks to the Good Samaritan Foundation of Haiti I am now within reach of achieving that. None of my siblings have been able to afford further education. I am hoping to finish my degree this year and help to take care of the medical needs in my village. One day I also dream of travelling a little and doing my Masters. I am grateful to all the donors who support this charity and help people to realize their dreams. Thank you!


Daniel - Agricultural Science degree.

"My Name is Daniel, I was born in my father’s town Baradères.

1 of 6 children of whom I am the eldest. my parents were forced to return to Ile a Vache, my mother’s town, in my childhood for economic reasons thinking that the island life would be better. Three years after their return, my father died. The situation became increasingly difficult. My mother returned to Baradères, leaving me with my grandmother, from then on, I lived with her until today.

My grandmother who loves me very much, had to work hard to take care of me including my first school fees. Despite her efforts, I could not go to school on an ongoing basis, there were always interruptions. I finished the classical school [secondary] with lots of difficulty. She was then 72 years old and could not work. I too could not find a job that could help me to continue my life.

I still have the desire to become someone who is brilliant in my life - I grew up with this dream and it feeds my mind, to bring my contribution in the island of Ile-a-Vache and  help my family to change their lives, to win the goal.

After completing high school I could not go to university because of economic means, the Good Lord sent me to meet a generous organization called Good Samaritan Foundation with Madame Mandy Thody. They assisted for two years in my studies in Agricultural Sciences,

I hope this year there is  someone in their generosity who could help me, God will reward you".

Pouchon -Civil Engineering degree.

Pouchon and his family are from the island of Ile a Vache. Like many young people on the Island he has not been able to go on to further education. Pouchon became involved with the Good Samaritan Foundation when they first gave him a bursary in 2013 to help him train as a translator to work with tourists.

Between work he spent much of his spare time helping in the school in La Hatte, working as teacher's assistant. When the dentists visit he volunteers his services. 
Pouchon  always dreamt of being a Civil Engineer and when Jude qualified  there was a place for him.

"I am a student in Civil Engineering. I finished my first year and I had good success. It is a great thing for me, for my family too! After my studies I'll give back many things to the community of Ile à Vache! There are many developments coming to the island such as the airport and roads. I'll also like to work as a teacher in mathematics at the foundation's school at the Island.

I would like to thank everyone who accepts to support me!

Blessings to you!  Thanks!"

Adeline - Advanced Nursing degree.

"My name is  Adeline and I have completed 2 years of advanced nursing and have 2 to go. Last year GSF was able to  give me a donated laptop which was a course requirement. I am  from a family of 13 children - 9 boys and 4 girls! My parents are elderly and suffer from the high blood pressure [endemic to Ile a Vache due to brackish water] and can no longer provide for their children. Several of us have had to leave their schooling.

The day I met Good Samaritan Foundation and had a favourable response to my wish to go to university, was the happiest of my life! 

I felt crushed after two years of hard work to think that they could not continue to support my studies - Any supporters would be a great help.

We hope you can help us. 

All the money that we receive at the Good Samaritan Foundation of Haiti will go to the students' education, books and living costs.  

Donors will have the satisfaction of knowing their money enables someone from a very disadvantaged background, in a rural village where most people are illiterate, to qualify as a professional - giving life-changing improvement to them, their families and their community! The students have all completed one or more years of their courses with good results. They help our medical and agricultural programs in the summer (see photo), help host volunteer workers and act as translators and co-ordinators for our projects. All would be happy to provide details of their progress and their lives and aspirations! Please ask your friends, any group/club you belong to, even your office colleagues - this is such a worthwhile and productive opportunity . Thank you for all your help!

story:
Short Summary / Kurzzusammenfassung

You can also fund Train of Hope Vienna with a direct payment to the bank account:-

Spendenkonto “Train of Hope” 
IBAN: AT21 2011 1827 5129 7500
BIC: GIBAATWWXXX

or donate here to pay by credit card or paypal.

Wir alle haben die Nachrichten gesehen und von den Menschen gehört, die aus Syrien und anderen Ländern fliehen, um ein neues Leben in Sicherheit in Europa anzufangen. Diese Menschen sind erschöpft und hungrig, wenn sie in Wien ankommen, und brauchen Nahrung, Kleidung und Zugtickets, um weiterreisen zu können.

Wir helfen ALLEN Flüchtenden, die über Wien reisen.

You've all seen the news and know about the people fleeing Syria and other countries who are trying to get to safe place to start a new life in Europe.  They arrive in Vienna tired and hungry and need food, clothes and a train ticket to take them on their way.

We're helping ALL refugees who pass through.

Ich heiße Phil Moran und bin Filmemacher und Journalist in Wien, Österreich.

I'm Phil Moran, a film-maker and journalist based in Vienna, Austria.

Was wir brauchen und was Sie tun:
What We Need & What You Get

Jeder Flüchtling benötigt jeweils ungefähr 250 Euro für Essen, eine ärztliche Untersuchung und ein Zugticket.

Wem hilft meine Spenden?  Jeder gespendete Euro hilft einer Familie, ein neues Leben zu beginnen.

Each refugee needs approximately 250 euros for food, a medical check up and a train ticket.  Every euro you donate helps a family start a new life.


The Risks / Gibt es Risiken?

Jeder einzelne Cent kommt direkt den Flüchtlingen zu Gute. Im unwahrscheinlichen Fall, dass nicht alles gespendete Geld direkt benötigt wird, wird der Überschuss an andere Hilfsorganisationen, die sich für Flüchtlinge einsetzen, gespendet.
Every penny donated will help someone, and in the unlikely event there is a surplus, it will be donated to other charities in the same field.


Other Ways You Can Help / Wie Sie sonst noch helfen können

Folgen Sie uns bitte auf Facebook: trainofhope

Please follow us on Facebook or come to Hauptbahnhof Vienna to  help out - hbfvie

story:
I. What We're Doing

The Dream Scholarship (DS) helps 5 undergraduate English students at the University of Panama (UP) reach their dream of getting a well-rounded English education and contributing to US-Panamanian cross-cultural understanding. It was created through a partnership between the United States embassy of Panama, the Fulbright Alumni Association in Panama, the University of Panama, and Murray State University (MSU) in Kentucky, USA. Named after Dr. Martin Luther King’s momentous speech, the program also encourages the students to use the knowledge they gain to serve their communities in Panama.

 II.Why We're Doing It

Many students at the UP want to have a deeper understanding of English in a U.S. cultural context. This includes everyday idioms, formal and informal speech, and native-speaker pronunciation. This desire comes at a time when Panama’s economy is developing quickly, and there is a large demand for fluent English speakers in the job market. The DS gives students the education they need to use English in a cultural context, as well as prepare them to compete in their own country’s emerging economy.

  III.How We're Doing It

5 students from the UP will participate in a two-month cultural immersion program at MSU. Students will be chosen based on their academic achievements, English level, and commitment to community service. During January and February of 2016, these students will:

· Take a 20 hour/week intensive English language immersion course

· Take a class on U.S. culture

· Field trips to nearby cities in the U.S. (ie. Louisville,KY; St. Louis, MO; Nashville, TN; Chicago, IL)

When they return to Panama, they will work with the U.S. embassy on several community service projects related to English teaching.

 IV.How You Can Help

The total cost per participant is estimated at $5,000. Donate $10, $25, $50,or $100 towards our goal! Your contribution will have a direct impact on these students' professional and personal lives!

story:
Who are we?

ADG is a non profit organization dedicated to developing projects that add value to rural communities and thus provide opportunities for families and children to have a better future through social innovation. 


What do we want to do?

We want to provide girls from Santa María de Jesús, Sacatepequez educational tablets.  Tablets provide all types of students an equal learning opportunity. Numerous educational apps are available which make learning interesting . Teachers can also use their tablet for selecting simulation games for skill training and gauging how well their students learned. These conveniences free them to concentrate more on teaching and less on testing and grading.  


Why are we doing this?

One of the main development issues in Guatemala, lie in a big part to the lack of education of its population. Guatemala has historically had a very low level of education, according to the National Statistics Insitute:

  • 75% is the percentage of illiteracy in many rural areas of Guatemala
  • 2/3 is the proportion of Guatemalan children living in poverty
  • USD 4 a day is the average daily income of a Guatemalan family in rural areas
  • 9 out of 10 is the proportion of school in rural areas of Guatemala that lack books
  • 60% is the percentage of entry-level jobs that require basic computer skills
  • 21% is the percentage of students of middle school that had access to computers
  • 1 in 10 is the proportion of Guatemalans in rural areas attending middle school
  • 1.8 is the average number of years that a guatemalan indigenous girl stays in school.
Not to mention the poor conditions that the few of public schools offer. This is mainly related with almost no investment from the government and deficient public policies that encourage quality public education. This project will benefit girls from elementary school (ages between 7 and 13 years old).
 

The Impact

By supporting small elementary public schools with technology, we are bringing new opportunities and tools to improve their chances of continuing high school. Most of them, never had interaction with computers nor internet. This will open a new world for them. Additionally, the main idea is to connect them with educational software and make their learning process more interesting. 

What do we need? 

We need to raise USD20,000 that will allow us to provide the 697 girls of the school in Santa María de Jesús with access to tablets, computers and internet. 
The tablets will include internet, educational apps, anti-theft device, parental control and anti-virus. This will also help to creat a training program for teachers and students. 

How your contribution will help?

Your contribution will be used to provide girls of Santa María de Jesús with technology, educational apps and access to english lessons. This means you will change the lives and opportunities of this girls, helping them to have better chances to keep in school and to apply to better jobs.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially. If you support our project, you can still help in the following ways:

  • Spread the word on Facebook, by inviting your friends to our site, or re-posting
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools

Thanks for your help in making a better education accessible to Guatemalan girls!

These conveniences free them to concentrate more on teaching and less on testing and grading.  


Why are we doing this?
One of the main development issues in Guatemala, lie in a big part to the lack of education of its population. Guatemala has historically had a very low level of education, according to the National Statistics Insitute:


75% is the percentage of illiteracy in many rural areas of Guatemala
2/3 is the proportion of Guatemalan children living in poverty
USD 4 a day is the average daily income of a Guatemalan family in rural areas
9 out of 10 is the proportion of school in rural areas of Guatemala that lack books
60% is the percentage of entry-level jobs that require basic computer skills
21% is the percentage of students of middle school that had access to computers
1 in 10 is the proportion of Guatemalans in rural areas attending middle school
1.8 is the average number of years that a guatemalan indigenous girl stays in school.


Not to mention the poor conditions that the few of public schools offer. This is mainly related with almost no investment from the government and deficient public policies that encourage quality public education. This project will benefit girls from elementary school (ages between 7 and 13 years old).

 The Impact
By supporting small elementary public schools with technology, we are bringing new opportunities and tools to improve their chances of continuing high school. Most of them, never had interaction with computers nor internet. This will open a new world for them. Additionally, the main idea is to connect them with educational software and make their learning process more interesting. 
   What do we need? 
We need to raise USD20,000 that will allow us to provide the 697 girls of the school in Santa María de Jesús with access to tablets, computers and internet. 

The tablets will include internet, educational apps, anti-theft device, parental control and anti-virus. This will also help to creat a training program for teachers and students. 


How your contribution will help?
Your contribution will be used to provide girls of Santa María de Jesús with technology, educational apps and access to english lessons. This means you will change the lives and opportunities of this girls, helping them to have better chances to keep in school and to apply to better jobs.


    Other Ways You Can Help
 
We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially. If you support our project, you can still help in the following ways:
Spread the word on Facebook, by inviting your friends to our site, or re-posting
Use the Indiegogo share tools
Thanks for your help in making a better education accessible to Guatemalan girls!

story:
What Is San Francisco Rock Project?

San Francisco Rock Project is a non-profit youth music school providing private, group and live music instruction to students of all skill levels from ages 7-18. We strive to offer the most accessible, personal and affordable learning experience possible for Bay Area youth.

Each year we offer tuition assistance to all students who qualify. This is where we need your help!  

We provide top-quality instruction to students from all walks of life who are interested in attending our program. We do have many students who can pay full tuition, but we are committed to offering our program at the lowest cost possible in an increasingly expensive city.

With the help of our incredible teaching staff, we've tackled over 60 themes at Rock Project, ranging in style from Jimi Hendrix to Tom Waits, and have also done tributes to artists including Patti Smith, Mike Patton, Ween, Jack White, Primus, Led Zeppelin, Fleetwood Mac, Heart, and many, many more. We also frequently offer an Original Songwriting program, which is geared to teaching students how to write their own songs and find their own voice.

Our students have received the privilege of sharing the stage with SFRP supporters Jello Biafra, Ty Segall, White Fence and tUnE-yArDs, among many others -- not to mention performing in countless Bay Area venues and circumstances, from street festivals to rock clubs to Davies Symphony Hall.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $30,000 for our 2016 Scholarship Fund. The priority allocation of every dollar we receive through this campaign will be to provide tuition assistance for enrolled families.

  • At this time, 20% of our student body receive either partial or full-ride tuition assistance. In 2016, we would like to at least maintain if not, in fact, increase that percentage.
  • It's important for us to be clear that our organization is committed to offering scholarships at this level, no matter what. Our scholarship fund is what will allow us to do so while maintaining our quality programming and paying fair rates to our exceptional staff, as well as keeping our facility fully operational and our hours both consistent and flexible.

"And what of the perks?" you cry. Well, other than the satisfaction of contributing to our aforedescribed goal:

  • Right now, our campaign's perks are simple. If you reside locally, you can opt to receive tickets to our year-end benefit at San Francisco's Rickshaw Stop on December 20th -- the 3rd annual Festive Festival of Bands. We don't do recitals. CURRENT LINEUP: Everyone Is Dirty! Kendra McKinley! The Great White Shark! PLUS: our entire performing student body, with tributes to Fiona Apple, Thin Lizzy and more, as well as a set of original songs!
  • We also have a selection of fantastic T-shirts, designed especially for us by local artiste extraordinaire Ferris Plock, that work double duty: they're extremely stylish and demonstrate your support for music education. They, too, can be yours.
  • KIRK HAMMETT, the lead guitar wizard from METALLICA, has done us a personal favor and signed some incredible, priceless items for us -- and now, for you! 5 LP copies of Master of Puppets -- AND one of our very own guitars! If you are (or you know) a diehard Metallica fan with the passion and budget to spare, these are the perks for you.

Our Community Is Your Community

By supporting San Francisco Rock Project, you are supporting community in more ways than you may realize. In teaching students the importance of both musical intellect and collaboration, we provide ambition and harmony to the youth of the San Francisco Bay Area -- characteristics that will stay with them for the rest of their lives.

The staff of the Rock Project both recognize and receive this; through Rock Project, they bring their life experience to their students, and in turn are transformed by working with them. Furthermore, our compact yet formidable group of brilliant teachers, combined, contribute their skills and musical visions to dozens of beloved bands, ensembles and performance projects -- reaching thousands and thousands of listeners. Because we can pay our teachers, they are able to continue to inspire in every aspect of their work.

...and Finally -- TELL EVERYONE!

Whether or not you are able to contribute -- and truly, as we are sure you know, every dollar helps! -- please consider sharing this campaign with everyone in your life who might be moved by our cause. $30,000 may seem like a lot to some, but with enough people and enough passion, it's an eminently achievable goal.

THANK YOU!
-Matthew "Shark" Shartsis, SFRP Music Director
and
Spencer Owen, SFRP Operations Manager

story:
About Us?

Nitsu Tesfa is a non-profit & non-governmental organisation dedicated to, giving orphans and street children a chance to education, learning materials, adequate clothing and meals during school hours.

Nitsu Tesfa was founded  in 2012 in Sydney, Australia by three friends who were inspired by a deep desire to help orphans and street children. We were funded by enthusiastic friends, family members and acquaintances living in Sydney and Melbourne area.

What We Are Doing?

In 2012 Nitsu Tesfa got involved in the meal program at Tsehay Chora Primary School in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The program was previously  taken care by the “Lunch for Education” project which was organised and funded by the school teachers. Our meal program provided lunch for 54 students in the beginning. Now, the number of students who benefit from the program have increased to 100 and also has added breakfast to it’s list.

As of now we have more than 50 members from Australia, Ethiopian, USA and Finland. Our members participate in planning, organizing fundraising events and volunteering in various project when needed.

In 2014 Nitsu Tesfa started collaborating with One Meal for One Child,  the group who are also helping underprivileged students in various schools. Between us, we deliver uniforms, bags, learning materials as well as breakfast and lunch during school days for 100 of Tsehay Chora’s students.

Where Your Money Goes

Amount needed for the Fiscal year 2015/2016:


* A package contains 12 exercise books, 2 pens, 2 pencils, 2 sharpener and 2 erasers.

We kindly request you to make a generous donation to enable us to continue with the lunch for education program we have undertaken in this school. Many individuals have shown positive response and we hope we get the same from your side as well.


Interested to follow up our works on facebook?

Please join our facebook pages to see what we have done so far and follow upcoming events regularly.

https://www.facebook.com/NitsuTesfa?fref=ts

https://www.facebook.com/groups/onepackforonechild/

https://www.facebook.com/groups/322780464443114/

story:
Summary

Windows of Hip Hop is a Bronx based economic development project dedicated to utilizing Hip Hop to teach. We are a educational chartered, Bronx, NY based non-profit registered with the State of New York. We have developed several curriculums and implemented several initiatives from Health and Fitness to Anti-Bullying campaigns; which we will share with over 15,000 students in the New York Tri-State Major Metropolitan Area! We are a strong group of business people, advocates, educators, entertainers, entrepreneurs, administrators, mothers and fathers who LOVE Hip Hop and recognize the true transformative power of this culture. 

Our campaign will build on our work with other non-profits and government agencies to improve students cognitive skills, task management, and appreciation for community. We seek to counter the malaise, disinterest, and modern angst by invigorating, inspiring, and being a catalyst for educators. 15,000 youth will be engaged, challenged then shown how valuable education is as well as their educators. 15,000 young students will be interested and intrigued by an art form they know and are familiar with. This leads to better behavior in class, in the home, and in the community. 

You can give 15,000 chances for a different outcome in a young person's life. Hip Hop has transformed the world but rap is just one of It's foundations. Your support will help reestablish the proper balance in our people, our families, and our culture.

What We Need & What You Get 

We have calculated a reasonable budget of $75,000 to complete our campaign. This will cover transportation, educational supplies, Audio & Visual aids, staff, rentals, fees, and the all important talent. We have some excellent celebrities, personalities, and entertainers committed to the project willing to show at cost! Let's all take advantage of those opportunities and build. As you can calculate, our programs are timely, realistic, and cost-effective. 

In return for your generosity, not only will we make mention of such . .  . all contributors will be given a link to a powerful, live performance by our team during the campaign! All the perks we chose are with you in mind. Things we'd want and would use. Memorabilia, music, Shirts and merchandise in addition to appearances, trips and television shows!!!

And if we fall short of our goal? No problem, we will reassess and adjust. Hip Hop teaches perseverance, ingenuity, and determination. We will see this done. 

The Impact

Our campaign is different because not only educators developed it. Grand Master Melle Mel was one of a few luminaries of Hip Hop who contributed to this project. We planned, studied, performed trial engagements, and created forums to process feedback. The result? A suite of proven programs which work. Students, educators, parents, and administrators are all engaged, focused, and become invested in the favorable outcomes we design. The contribution you make impacts over 10 fold. It allows a great team of stakeholders to put into effect a challenging, persuasive argument to counter some of the most jaded of individuals like today's students. 

Our team has worked in the past on similar programs with non-profits, after school programs, and agencies. The approach is similar but the delivery is pin point perfect. Hip Hop IS a powerful medium and we are experts at sharing effectively. Our video highlights one of the groups in the Bronx who engaged with our program and proves the worth of our team. This was just a small scale sample of the greater impact your contribution will have. With our music, shirts, or banners you reemphasize our work and help counter the narrative which tries to ignore Hip Hop's positive influence. If you LOVE Hip Hop you can provide the opportunity for over 15,000 youths to appreciate what you know is true! 

Risks & Challenges

WE are embarking on an aggressive campaign to change the minds of 15,000 young people. We understand the very real challenge it is to connect with the youth in a meaningful way. Communication gaps, ADD, and modern distractions have disconnected the youth like never before. Some may believe nothing can crack that armor. That today, children are scary they don't listen but rather intimidate those trying to help. These are the same obstacles Hip Hop has beaten before. 

Apathy, gang violence, disrespect for education, elders, and women. Hip Hop is more than rap music. It is expression, Freedom with Responsibility, communal, and goal oriented. Our Board and Executive Team are fully qualified to fulfill this engagement and carry this program to it's conclusion. We are committed to proving the value of education and Hip Hop's true worth. 

Our Pioneers won the 70s. They defeated  gang violence and economic disenfranchisement with the only tools they had available. Music playing systems, ingenuity, persistence, perseverance, and their own bodies. Be a witness as we do it again.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate all of your consideration. We are all in different circumstances and just because you may not be able to send money now, doesn't mean you do not matter. Hip Hop survived on word of mouth! We now have social media and technology. 

You can share our pages, blast our posts, and pump our music and videos. The more who see the fund , the more chances to reach our goal. Share our program. Call your friends, reblog, post, email, fax, rhyme about us, create a poster. However you decide, you will be assisting to spread the word. Introduce them to our program and drive them to our page. We are doing great work and your support will make sure the job is done right!

story:
(Traducciones en Español e italiano aquí)

https://www.facebook.com/Maestro-Stefano-Monterotondo-Roma-1620540011542946/timeline/

Who are you helping?

I'm an italian Montessori teacher and, after living some years in Spain and Perù, I came back to my small town next to Rome, working in public primary school where I want to use Montessori materials but ... public school has no funds to buy them!

What we need?

We need mathematics, language and other subjects furniture to apply Montessori method. Some Montessori teachers kindly lent me some furniture to start, but I'll need to return them and to buy more furniture. So, the campaign has 3 steps

1) Decimal System furniture (400 E)
2) Furniture lent by other Montessori teachers (500 E)
3) More subjects furniture (550 Euro)


What You Get?

You'll get a better world, with 20 (or more) future Montessori citizens: more creative, able and correct in community life (as a Virginia University study demonstrated in 2006).


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please let your friends know this campaign! You can use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thank you very much!

story:
3 years ago we made Bodyguard Skills to create a one-stop educational site for bodyguard aspirants and professionals alike. The site has been running as a non-profit project since, with the support of several veterans within our trade. These include Tony Scotti, author of numerous books ie. "Vehicle dynamics professional driving techniques", Mike Proctor author of "antidote for a stalker" and Craig Pedersen, the author of "Basic Bodyguarding Skills" to name but a few of our contributors.

So far we have created in excess of 10 hours of e-learning movies about bodyguarding, along side numerous written pages of material, surveys and a mini-guide.

Unfortunately we have run out of funds to make the next 20 hours of educational movies for personal protection / bodyguard students.

Actually we already filmed more than 30 hours of raw film, but unfortunately our tech-dude has set his eye on another project. Therefore we need to buy the services (pre-production, editing, sound and post-production) from an external channel.

This is where YOU come in!

Obviously we need some money, but we also need someone to spread the word.

You can see the project on www.bodyguardskills.com

Or maybe visit our facebook page on: https://www.facebook.com/BodyguardSkills

 Why do the world need bodyguardskills.com?

Well, the personal protection trade is one of the oldest professions in the world. It is also an honorable and revered profession, saving many lives.

Unfortunately it has become a specialized segment with hundreds of training providers, whereof many exist only to take young hopeful peoples money. A bodyguard course may easily set a student back 5-10 000 dollars.

Bodyguardskills.com delivers knowledge to the many pre-students, so they can choose a training provider on an informed platform. Second, we deliver much information on the page, which training providers simply can't or don't, due to lack of time or lack of operational experience (They may have other experiences equally important).

We help young people save money, so they can train to save other peoples lives.

What if we don't make the US 50 000?

We will use whatever we get in, to keep the site afloat. If there's any money to spend, we will spend them on finishing the film we've already shot. Depending on the quality, one hour of film cost about US 5 000 to finish (We may need to lower our expectations).

What if we make more than US 50 000?

Depending on the numbers, we will probably finish all the existing raw film, rebuild our website and if there's any money left; shoot some more educational movies! - In short; Every dime will go into production and maintenance.

story:
Time to Dive In!

There are many children who cannot afford swimming lessons and the drowning statistics in South Africa are much too high – particularly within poorer communities where many children never have the opportunity to learn to swim. The truth is, drowning is one of the leading causes of accidental death for children in South Africa, and it is 100% preventable!

Love to Langa is a US-based 501(c)3 charity that has taken on the vision of Philippi Children’s Centre (PCC) to build an indoor swim school in Philippi Township, a poor farming community near Cape Town.  In accordance with Love to Langa and PCC’s vision to teach underprivileged children and adults to swim, Headstart Swim School will join hands with Love to Langa and operate a successful swim school within the Philippi community, which does not have the luxury of indoor swimming facilities and qualified instructors.  Indeed, the closest indoor pool is 15 miles away. Once completed, Headstart will train pupils and community members to teach at the school and eventually take over the administration. 

We have an opportunity to make a difference

Few disadvantaged children have ever seen a swimming pool. The parents are unable to afford swimming lessons and many schools don’t have the resources or facilities to offer them.

Love to Langa, PCC and Headstart aim to reduce the risk of drowning in farming and urban communities near the coast by teaching underprivileged school-going children to swim by taking them through the learn-to-swim program in a safe, non-threatening and fun environment.

The locals have stepped up so now its up to us!

Many local businesses around the Cape Town and Philippi area have already committed in-kind donations for all the materials needed to build the swim academy! All that is left is for Love to Langa to raise the cost for the labor to build it!

Total labor cost to build a brand new swim academy is only $25,000!

The impact it will have on the children

  • It is a vital life skill
  • It reduces drowning
  • It provides a healthy lifestyle
  • It creates recreation for children from underprivileged communities
  • talented swimmers will be sponsored for further development
The Learn to Swim Program will teach the children

  • Water safety


  • Water orientation
  • Basic swimming strokes
  • Survival techniques

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help us!

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Here are a few examples of the children's paintings that are offered as "Neck Deep" & "Dive In" perks!

Receive USDA Organic Coffee when you support us through the "Chest High" perk!

When you support us through the "Dive In" perk you will also receive this wonderful photo book "Through Children's Eyes"

Here are few of our Amazing Sponsors! Please visit their websites to learn more about them!

story:
STORY (French version can be found below)

Pierre and Pascal are two young orphaned Congolese refugee brothers living in Zambia who are trying to achieve their education, break the cycle of violence and to help make a difference in the world.

In 2012, Pierre and Pascal’s family home in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) was attacked by militia targeting their ethnic group. Their father and mother were murdered and Pierre and Pascal and their younger sister were assaulted and beaten by the rebels.  In all of the commotion the two young brothers managed to escape, slipping into the jungle and running for their lives. They never heard from their sister again. Eventually, after months of hiding, the brothers were smuggled into Zambia, where they were granted refugee status.  However, shortly after they arrived Pascal was attacked by a group of youth who chased him into the heart of the city where he became completely disoriented, lost and separated from his brother.  Pascal lived on the streets of Lusaka, the capital of Zambia, for over 3 months, constantly searching for his brother. Pierre also spent endless days searching for his younger brother to no avail.  Completely devastated, Pierre decided to seek protection at a refugee camp and turned up at the camp where I worked for the United Nations.  Pierre was inconsolable about his brother’s loss, but no one believed his story or offered him support.  However, there was something about Pierre’s eloquence, sincerity and profound determination that I could not ignore and I decided to help him.  With my assistance, after only a few weeks of phone calls and searches in Lusaka, the capital of Zambia, a  local doctor informed us that he had seen Pascal in a certain  neighbourhood and with his help a miracle occurred; Pierre and Pascal were reunited. 

After being reunited, the boys lived together in a mud hut in the refugee camp where I worked. I witnessed their profound positivity and generosity, which spread throughout  the community.  They played soccer with other youth, help build houses for elderly refugees and made many friends. They also possessed a great intellectualism, constantly discussing peace and conflict and the injustices of the world. They kept up to date on world politics and the voting record of United Nations Security Council members.  However, the boys also were extremely discouraged.  With no high school or college in the camp, they felt useless and unable to rebuild their lives.  As refugees, they were also legally barred from any employment in Zambia.  It was in this state of discouragement that I came up with the idea of linking them with local donors in Canada, my home country, in order to pursue their education. 

Fate took care of the rest.  In late 2013, I found myself having dinner at my best friend's family home in Montreal when her mother, a local dedicated and passionate family physician, Dr. Jeannette Janzen, shared her desire to 'sponsor' a child as her most recent sponsored child had aged out. I immediately shared with her Pierre and Pascal's story, and right there, in between the food and dishes at the dinner table, she wrote out the first of what became countless cheques that she donated to the boys' well-being.  Not only did Dr. Janzen financially dedicate herself to Pierre and Pascal,  single-handedly paying for their shelter, food and education,  but she also quickly became 'mom', as the boys started to e-mail her with questions about adolescence, studying, jobs and everything between.  Together, the two of us became the boys' lifeline, providing financial necessities, but also moral support. 

With Dr. Janzen's help Pierre and Pascal moved to  Lusaka, and re-embarked on their studies that had been so brutally interrupted in DRC.  Since 2014, a new chapter in their lives has began: Pierre has been studying in a Foundations of Medicine program at a Zambian University and is on track to be accepted into medical school next year- he was even recently chosen as Foreign Student of the month, and Pascal is working hard at high school, passing all of his classes and making many friends along the way. Not only do the boys desire to complete their studies, but they also hope to give back to their community and help change the cycle of violence that has plagued Africa. Pierre hopes to become a gynecologist to fight for equality and women’s rights, and Pascal wants to be a UN Pilot, but they need financial support to achieve their educational dreams.

Dr. Janzen and I created a framework for the boys' support, formalizing the transfers and garnering the support of other dedicated local Montreal volunteers.  Together with the boys we created a budget and a plan, building on our friendship and trust, as well as my knowledge of the Zambian economy. Every 3 months they submit a budget, and using the donations collected, I transfer money according to what has been planned in advance.  However, more support is needed: it costs approximately $350/month to cover the boys’ basic necessities such as food, shelter and transport, and tuition for Pierre’s university is $2 250 per year and high school is $450 per year.  We are seeking to raise at least $24 000 in order to help support the boys until they have completed their studies and they are able to realize their dreams.

Thank you for your contributions- everything helps. 


FRENCH VERSION:


Le texte ici-bas a été écrit par une jeune femme qui a travaillé pour les Nations

Unies pendant quelque temps dans un camp de réfugiés en Zambie. Nous

l’appellerons Rebecca.

Pierre et Pascal sont deux jeunes réfugiés orphelins congolais vivant en Zambie

qui tentent de compléter leur éducation scolaire, de briser le cycle de la violence

et d'essayer de faire la différence dans notre monde.

En 2012, la demeure de la famille de Pierre et Pascal située dans le Sud Kivu, en

République Démocratique du Congo (RDC) a été attaquée par la milice qui s'en

prenait à leur groupe ethnique. Leur père et leur mère ont été assassinés alors

que Pierre, Pascal et leur jeune soeur ont été attaqués et battus par les rebelles.

Dans toute cette folie, les deux jeunes frères ont réussi à échapper à leurs

assaillants et ont couru à travers la jungle pour sauver leur peau.

Malheureusement ils n'ont jamais eu des nouvelles de leur jeune soeur.

Après plusieurs mois de marche, en se cachant du mieux qu'ils pouvaient, les

deux frères ont finalement réussi à entrer clandestinement en Zambie où ils ont

reçu leur statut de "réfugié".

Cependant, peu de temps après leur arrivée, Pascal, le plus jeune des deux

frères, fut attaqué par un groupe de jeunes qui l'ont poursuivi à travers la ville de

Lusaka où il se retrouva complètement désorienté et séparé de son frère Pierre.

A la recherche constante de son grand frère, Pascal a survécu dans les rues de

la ville pendant 3 mois.

Sans aide et ne connaissant personne, Pierre, de son côté, cherchait également

son frère dans cette grande ville inconnue. Complètement dévasté, il décide de

se rendre dans un camp pour réfugiés afin de trouver un peu de protection et

s'est retrouvé dans le camp où Rebecca travaillait en tant que membre des

Nations Unies.

Suite à la disparition de son frère, Pierre était inconsolable, mais personne ne

voulait croire à son histoire et surtout personne ne voulait l'aider dans ses

recherches. Ses paroles, sa sincérité, mais surtout sa profonde détermination de

trouver son frère, sont venues me chercher au plus profond de moi et j'ai décidé

de l'aider.

Avec l'aide de mon assistante et après quelques semaines, de nombreux appels

et quelques aller-retour dans Lusaka, un médecin local nous a informés qu'il

avait aperçu Pascal dans un quartier de la ville. Un miracle s'est enfin produit: les

deux frères étaient enfin à nouveau réunis.

Après leur réunion, les deux jeunes ont vécu dans une hutte faite de boue, dans

le camp où je continuais à travailler. Je fus témoin de leur attitude profondément

positive, de leur gratitude et de leur générosité à travers la communauté. Ils

jouaient au soccer avec les plus jeunes, aidaient à construire des maisons en

boue pour les réfugiés les plus vieux et se sont faits de nombreux amis. Ils

possédaient aussi un très grand savoir, parlaient perpétuellement de paix, de

conflit et d'injustice dans le monde. Ils se tenaient au courant de la politique

mondiale et des votes des Membres du Conseil de Sécurité des Nations Unies.

Malgré leur grande patience et leur optimisme débordant, certains jours ils

vivaient des moments d'extrême découragement. En effet, le camp était sans

école, ni collège, ni université où pouvoir continuer leur éducation. Ils se

sentaient inutiles et incapables de reconstruire leur vie. Aussi en tant que

réfugiés, il leur état impossible de travailler en Zambie. C'est dans cette

ambiance de découragement que j'ai eu l'idée de faire un lien entre des

donateurs du Canada, mon pays, et nos deux jeunes orphelins pour qu'ils

puissent poursuivre leurs études. Le destin s'est occupé du reste.

Fin 2013, j'étais invitée à souper dans la famille d'une de mes meilleures amies à

Montréal. Sa mère, un médecin de famille passionnée et dévouée, m'a parlé de

son désir de parrainer les deux jeunes. J'ai toute de suite raconté l'histoire de

Pierre et de Pascal, et juste là, entre le plat et le dessert, elle a sorti son chéquier

et m'a fait le premier de nombreux chèques à suivre. Non seulement Dr Janzen

s'est dévouée financièrement pour Pierre et Pascal en payant toute seule pour le

logement, la nourriture et leur éducation mais elle est devenue très rapidement

"Mom" pour ces deux jeunes orphelins qui ont commencé à lui envoyer des

courriels remplis de questions à propos de l'adolescence, des études, de futurs

emplois assortis d'anecdotes de tous genres. Ensemble, Dr Janzen et

moi-même sommes devenues une bouée de secours pour ces deux jeunes non

seulement financièrement, mais aussi un gros support moral.

Avec l'aide de Dr Janzen, Pierre et Pascal ont pu déménager à Lusaka et

reprendre leurs études interrompues si brutalement en République du Congo.

Depuis 2014, un nouveau chapitre de leur vie a commencé: Pierre étudie dans

un programme de "fondation de la médecine" dans une université de Zambie et

est sur le point d'être accepté l'année prochaine à l’École de Médecine. Il a

récemment été choisi comme étudiant étranger du mois, alors que Pascal

travaille fort à l'école secondaire, réussissant tous ses cours et se faisant

beaucoup d'amis. Non seulement le désir de nos deux jeunes est de réussir

brillamment leurs études mais ils espèrent aussi redonner à leur communauté et

espèrent changer le cycle de la violence qui ravage l'Afrique. Pierre espère

devenir gynécologue et de se battre pour l'égalité et les droits des femmes,

tandis que Pascal rêve de devenir pilote pour les Nations Unies. Mais pour

atteindre leur rêve, ils ont besoin de support financier.

Dr Janzen et moi-même avons créé une structure financière pour le support des

jeunes en organisant les transferts d'argent et mettant sur pied un groupe de

volontaires locaux dédiés à leur cause. Ensemble avec les garçons nous avons

mis sur place un budget et un plan basés sur la confiance ainsi que sur ma

connaissance de l'économie de la Zambie. Tous les trois mois, ils soumettent

leur budget et un résumé de leurs dépenses. Je transfère l'argent en fonction de

leur plan trimestriel.

Cependant, nous avons besoin de plus de donations. Cela coûte environ $350

par mois pour les besoins de base de nos deux jeunes incluant le logement, la

nourriture et le transport. Les frais pour l'université de Pierre sont de $2250 par

année et pour l'école secondaire de Pascal $450 par année.

Nous cherchons à récolter au moins $24 000 afin d'aider les garçons jusqu'à la

fin de leur scolarité et leur permettre de réaliser leur rêves.

Merci pour vos contributions. Tous les montants aident. Encore merci.

Merci pour vos contributions. Tous les montants aident. Encore merci.

story:
I) Presentation of our NGO

Vidyanikethan is a Bangalore-based NGO, in Karnataka’s state, South India. 

It's a non-profit making organization founded in 1988 by Madame Susheela. Its goal is to improve the lives and livelihoods of people from the vulnerable, marginalized and under-developed sections of the society by targeting mainly the children and women from low-income families in urban areas. It acts in four spheres : health, education, natural resources' management and socio-economic development. Learn more about us : http://www.vidyanikethan.org

Bangalore has more than 8 million inhabitants. This rate is increasing and leading to slum expansion because of migrants, who desert marginalized rural areas. In 2003, Bangalore had 473 slums increasing to 597 in 2013. 25 and 35 % of Bangalore's population live in makeshift shelters. Among those people, children are obliged working for their parents, because of the cost to survive and are not enabled getting education. Most of the time, they work in factories or construction sites where their mental and physical health is endangered.

II) Presentation of our project "Vidyanikethan School"

Thanks to Sri Vidyanikethan school, the organization has an answer to this problem. It is a Karanataka State acknowledged education institution, located in Jaraganahalli district, which has a slum population of 12 350 people. Its goal is to offer education to slum children, who cannot afford a public or a private school. Between 85 and 90 % of the 200 Vidyanikethan’s children live in Jaraganahalli’s slums. The children’s parents are often migrants working on construction sites, as peddler on roadsides or working in any other low-income jobs. On average, the household’s income doesn’t exceed 3 000 rupees monthly, which represents almost 47, 21 US$. 

Employing 60 members of which 20 skilled teachers and 3 drivers for the school bus service, the NGO takes in children from pre-nursery to 10th standard. 

They have school everyday, from 9:30 am until 3:30 pm from Monday till Friday and from 9:30 am until 12:00 pm on Saturday. They are also taught identical teachings from other public and private schools in order to get the same opportunities : Kannada (the local language), Hindi, English, sciences, mathematics, social studies and computer science. The remaining hours cover extra-activities such as choir, dance, drawing and stories/essay writing. Besides those teachings, it is also life in community’s values and discipline which are passed to the pupils.

The second important task for Vidyanikethan is to raise the parents’ awareness about education’s importance :  more often, they are illiterate and don’t understand the education’s stake. So, they prefer to send their children working to ensure a supplementary income for the family. In order to avoid the repetition of a vicious circle “poverty – child labor – analphabetism – poverty”, teachers and parents usually meet each other to assess the child’s progresses and acquaint the school program. The regular interactions between parents and teachers increase the parent’s interest for their children’s education, which has for consequence to reduce the school drop-out rate.

We promote education for all. Slum children have the right to get a better future !

III) What we need 

Like we wrote before, the parents don’t have the financial means to send their children to school. Vidyanikethan’s main objective is to remedy this problem by looking for donators who could help financially for the schooling by paying a contribution. After realising a survey in the slums, Vidyankethan determinates the number of children who will get the financial help. For this school year 2015-2016, 190 students need to be sponsored. We already found sponsors for 90 children, but 100 are still missing (see below).

It is up to you to decide how much you want to give and for what (see every sum below), every sum will be very useful ! Schooling a child for one year costs 16 321 rupees (≈ 255 US$). We only ask to the parents to participate to their child's education by paying an amount of 550 rupees ( 8, 65 US$), while it is possible for the donators to pay until 7 680 rupees (120 US$). The full sum's details and its use will be explained below.

We precise that our school doesn’t get any government aid. 

So, for this school year 2015-2016, we need:  

Children needing to be sponsored

Children already sponsored

TOTAL

Number of children

100

90

190

Cost

16 321 x 100 = 1 632 100 R (25 550 US$)

90 x 16 321 = 1 468 890 R

(≈ 22 971,14 US$)

1 632 100 + 1 468 890  = 3 100 990 R

(≈ 48487 US$)

In conclusion, we need to collect the amount of 1 632 127,50 rupees (25 550 US$) and pay the annual schooling fees for the 100 needing children. 

You can help us by paying the amount of your choice : 

- 120 US$, for the schooling fees

- 70 US$, to buy two uniforms, two pairs of shoes and sockets for a child (uniform is obligatory in all Indian schools)

- 45 US$, to buy all the school books (6, for each teaching)

- 35 US$, to pay the school bus service for one year

- 25 US$, to pay all the school outings

- 15 US$, to buy a school bag

- 10 US$, to buy a complete pencil case (including one pencil case, 5 pencils, 5 pens, 2 erasers and 2 glues)

- 5 US$, to buy 6 notebooks

IV) What you will get in exchange

Even if the total amount we are looking for couldn't be achieved, the total sum will be used to help children. Anyway, you will be informed by a report sent by email about the way we used the collected money and what we achieved thanks to it. 

For each amount, you will get a special return to make always sure that all Vidyanikethan's staff and especially the child you help to remember what you did and what he/she achieved thanks to you. Don't forget that no matter how much you give, you already contribute a lot :

- you contribute to assure a future to a child by breaking the vicious circle poverty – children labor – analphabetism – poverty : offering better career’s opportunities and a better life to a child, his/her family and his/her future family

- you contribute to promote education and to valorize childhood's protection and children's rights

Many of our former students have found jobs as employees, in computer science,... and now, they help their very proud parents financially while they can prepare a bright future for their (future) children !

We are a very motivated NGO and some of us work here since more than 25 years. It is very difficult and it takes time to find sponsors/donators and raise money, but we never give up, because everyday, and everytime we see our children so happy to go to school and their smiling parents, we remember what we are fighting for. By promoting education, we also promote equality. Slum children have the right to a second chance too !  

We thank you a lot for your attention. Please don't forget to share our page and talk about our project !

story:
I have a dream that French West Africa region will create entrepreneurial heroes to solve the proverty, and together we can make this dream comes true! More on medium.com.


I want to tell the story of an African entrepreneur's trip to the valley to attend Draper University for 8 weeks.

Make a donation , for Start-Up Education of West Africans Entrepreneurs 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Qui?

Née en 2012 , Wepioneer est la plateforme des Entrepreneurs des pays émergents. C’est aussi une aventure entrepreneuriale Ivoirienne au cœur des Écosystèmes Start-Up Mondial. L’Objectif de cette initiative est de transmettre et partager avec le plus grand nombre l’envie d’entreprendre par l’organisation de workshop et d’Atelier de formation gratuits. Pour cette Deuxième Edition nous 

Que comptons-nous faire ?

Notre projet pour cette deuxième édition est de s’y rendre et revenir pour organiser des workshop, ateliers et conférences sur les méthodologies que nous aurons apprises la-bàs, tout en mettant en relation la silicon valley et la #FrenchtechAfrique.Par ailleurs , nous voulons au sortir de notre immersion à Draper University nous voulons  faire de #wepioneerun fellowship program pour entrepreneurs francophone dans les pays émergents avec 3 leviers à savoir :

L’information (via un blog) , La Formation (via un programme de Start-Up Education  en ligne et en présentielle) et L’immersion (Exploration dans les Ecosystèmes).

Qu'est-ce qui nous motive à réaliser cette initiative ?

L’analyse que nous avons faite à la suite de notre premier roadtrip dans les écosystèmes de la silicon valley, silicon halley, Silicon Cap, Silicon Savanah, nous permit de comprendre qu’il n’y a pas de connexion entre les écosystèmes matures des pays du Nord avec ceux du Sud.

70% des ventures capitalist company de la silicon valley n’investissent pas en Afrique et il y’a uniquement une présence de 1% de start-up Africaines dans la silicon valley: (par exemple Dropify qui en 2013 était la première Start-Up Africaine du Programme 500Startup). Il n’existe que 3 programmes Start-up en Afrique ayant un lien fort avec la silicon valley à savoir : Savannah Fund , Mestwalter , 88mph (tous étant anglophones).

Comment allons-nous procéder ?

Wepionneer II aura donc plusieurs étapes à savoir :

– La campagne de crowdfunding , qui aura lieu sur un Mois , en vue de mobiliser des fonds.

– Le Hero Training , la formation d’Hero de Draper University sur une période 7 semaines.

– Le Sharing  Expérience ,l’idée est de revenir en Afrique et partager son Expérience avec les jeunes Africains , qui n’ont pas la chance d’avoir accès à ces types de formations autour de entrepreneuriat.


Qui sommes-nous ?

A quoi servira la collecte ?
Il ​prend en compte les billets d'avion , les frais ​de séjour et de visa, les assurances sur ​notre matériel, les transports,​et les frais de formations de Draper University.​       ​Nous avons donc besoin de vous pour rejoindre cette belle aventure et nous aider à boucler notre budget.

story:
Short Summary

I am an artist/writer/actor based in Kathmandu for the past ten years. My works have been shown widely (London, Delhi, Doha, Kathmandu etc), my writings have appeared regularly on Frieze, Asian Art News, Sahitya Akademi, National Book Trust, Depart, Hyperallergic etc. I have played leading roles in English language theatre productions of Nepal. 

As an active member of the arts community of Nepal I am shaken by the lack of infrastructure and support available to the art and theatre community here. I am bringing together respected gallerists, art critics, social workers and directors to form a fund that will help rehabilitate and at least partially reimburse medical expenses borne by the earthquake-devastated arts and theatre professionals of Nepal.

What We Need & What You Get

You can contribute as little as USD 10 though we need to raise a minimum total of USD 3000 since we are hoping to support at least 20 affected arts/theatre professionals ($250 each). This will help rebuild homes, pay for medical bills and cremation rites, provide basic support to those rendered unemployed by the quake and also help repair damaged art/theatre spaces. 

An advisory committee comprising eminent gallerists, art critics, artists, social workers, theatre directors and performers will distribute the funds to needy individuals and organizations through : a) nomination by existing and credible art/theatre institutions; b) direct outreach to the community.  Jennifer Higgie (Co-Editor of Frieze), Deborah Merola (Founder-Director of One World Theatre), Ingrid Cheron of Newa Chen, Yulia Koirala (Founder-Director Sushila Art Academy) are on the advisory committee of this initiative.

A complete record of the funds received and distributed will be made available online.

The more funds we receive, the more people will receive help. But we look forward to supporting at least 20 people/families at this point.

Each and every contribution will be mentioned and appreciated on our online records.

Contribution above USD 500 will be awarded with a signed print of an artwork  OR a token of appreciation from the beneficiary (artist/theatre professional/organization).

The Impact

Your contribution will  help save lives and rebuild futures of talented and brilliant art & theatre professionals who can hardly make ends meet even during normal times. Nepal is a new republic and just recovering from a decade-long civil war, and is yet to have a Constitution even. The art economy here is next to nonexistent and though creative brilliance is more than abundant, its systematic promotion is almost nil. The creative community on the other hand is large in number.This leaves most arts/theatre professionals in a double-bind of poverty and declining productivity. A small contribution from you will provide these artists and performers with material relief and help them regain faith in themselves and the possibility of a future.

story:
Hi I'm Keehlan (the one in the middle),  I'm 15 and in year 9. My interests are swimming, Netflix and sleeping. I like long walks to the fridge and taking selfies with may cat, Boris.

I've been given the oppurtinity though Rotary to go on a 12 month student exchange to the U.S. the overall cost is around $9000, I want to pay for at least a third of it because that's the type of bloke I am. I want to riase $3000 on my own to help pay for my trip.

    What We Need & What You Get
    (When you donate...)
  • Money goes straight into paying for the exchange 
  • Money will pay for airfares, schooling costs, return airfare, personal insurances, Internal travel costs, day to day living expenses of the student and an emergency fund 
  • When you donate more than $25AUD you get something as a reward

The Impact

The project is valuable because it extends understand across the world, for me personally it increases my personal development,  I’ll come back as a youth leader, a stronger voice in my community and with an experience of a life time.

Risks & Challenges

·  If I can’t pay my own way the financial burden falls to my parents, which I don’t want to see happen

  • I won't be able to see my cat for 12 months
  • I won't be able to take selfies with my cat for 12 months

story:
Sam Schwartz, a  13 year-old baseball player from El Paso, Texas decided that 100 years is long enough for kids not to have a grass field to play on at Lydia Patterson Institute in South El Paso. His goal is to raise funds that will go directly towards building a multi-purpose field for Lydia Patterson Institute and the children of Segundo Barrio, the third poorest zip code in the United States.     

  Established over 100 years ago, Lydia Patterson Institute, only minutes from the U.S-Mexico border has been dedicated to building bridges between two countries, two cities, and two cultures. As the only United Methodist institution on the border, LPI is committed to forming bilingual and bicultural leaders for the church and the region.    Excellence and outstanding achievement has been the trademark of LPI students. Graduation rates of students exceed 95% of those entering as freshmen and over 98% of the graduates continue their education at colleges across the United States. The graduation class of 2010, for example, earned 2.1 million dollars in competitive college scholarships.

   This project is important to Sam because he wants to give back to the school that helped his grandmother get an education and achieve the first college degree in her family. Sports are a way to create strong leaders and help with well being and self esteem.

  The initial funds raised for this project will go directly toward the installation of sprinklers, sod, and basic equipment for soccer and baseball, two sports important to keeping the students competitive nationally. 
 

 Everything we raise will go directly towards these items and every dollar counts.

 The impact this field will have goes beyond Lydia Patterson and Sam Schwartz.This Field of Dreams will be a beacon of hope and pride in a resilient neighborhood and will help to heal this world.

http://www.lydiapattersoninstitute.org/history-of-lpi.html


video by Peter Svarzbein / www.mongovision.com

Graduation rates of students exceed 95% of those entering as freshmen and over 98% of the graduates continue their education at colleges across the United States. The graduation class of 2010, for example, earned 2.1 million dollars in competitive college scholarships.
   This project is important to Sam because he wants to give back to the school that helped his grandmother get an education and achieve the first college degree in her family. Sports are a way to create strong leaders and help with well being and self esteem.

  The initial funds raised for this project will go directly toward the installation of sprinklers, sod, and basic equipment for soccer and baseball, two sports important to keeping the students competitive nationally.  
 Everything we raise will go directly towards these items and every dollar counts.
 The impact this field will have goes beyond Lydia Patterson and Sam Schwartz.This Field of Dreams will be a beacon of hope and pride in a resilient neighborhood and will help to heal this world.
http://www.lydiapattersoninstitute.org/history-of-lpi.html

video by Peter Svarzbein / www.mongovision.com

story:
Who we are

We are 2 students from Victoria BC, Canada. We are working together with our IGS 9 teacher to raise money to upgrade a library in Gwaragwara Uganda.

Our teacher Mr. Neufeld dancing with some locals from Gwaragwara


Our Goal

We are working to raise money to upgrade a library in the small rural village of Gwaragwara, Uganda. As technology improves, we realize the importance of teaching the children in Gwaragwara how to use computers, and that's why we are using a portion of the money raised for computers, and solar panels to power them. Through this, we can provide a chance for the children of Gwaragwara to better their future, and learn skills all children deserve.

Children in the village just having a good time

Our Legacy

IGS has already made a difference in the lives of the people of Gwaragwara. A few years ago, we raised enough money to build a small library. The outcome was greater than we could have ever imagined, with children coming from kilometres away to use the library. The success was so great that there was often a long line at the door waiting to get in (pictured below). That's why we believe it is important to expand the library, and add computers, and books.

Children in GwaraGwara waiting outside the door to get into the current library

Why Donate?

Gwaragwara is a very small, and underprivileged community full of enthusiastic learners and friendly people. All of these very grateful people deserve to have the chance to learn as we do here in Canada. Every penny donated will go directly towards the library.

PLEASE ALSO JOIN OUR THUNDERCLAP HERE TO SUPPORT:
https://www.thunderclap.it/projects/27475-gr-9s...
